levels.title: Level 1: Greetings
levels.description: Learn the specific greetings for Morning, Afternoon, and Evening. Cultural focus: Why you must greet before asking for anything.
learningObjectives: Learn 10 new Igbo words related to greetings
Understand when to use different greetings

vocabulary.culturalNote: Used to welcome guests into your home.
Morning greeting used from dawn until around noon.
Used to say 'you're welcome' or 'no worries'.

vocabulary.example: Ka ọ dị, echi ga-ahụ gị.
Ọ bụ echi, jee nke ọma!
vocabulary.culturalNote: Used when parting with plans to meet next day.

grammarPoints.explanation: Igbo greetings often consist of a time-specific phrase followed by 'ọma' (good) or a simple 'Kedu?' to ask about well-being.
The typical response to 'Kedu?' is 'Ọ dị mma' (It is fine) or a similar phrase. It is polite to ask 'Kedu?' back after responding.
examples: A: Kedu? B: Ọ dị mma, kedu?
grammarPoints.pattern: Question: Kedu? Answer: Ọ dị mma

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Nnọọ, Ada!
dialogue.translation: Welcome, Ada!

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Nnọọ, Chioma! Kedu?
dialogue.translation: Welcome, Chioma! How are you?

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma, daalụ. Kedu?
dialogue.translation: I'm fine, thank you. How are you?

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Ka ọ dị!
dialogue.translation: I'm fine. Goodbye!

culturalNotes.title: Importance of Greetings
culturalNotes.content: In Igbo culture, greetings are essential. It is considered rude to start a conversation without first greeting the person properly. Greetings show respect and acknowledge the other person's presence.

culturalNotes.title: Elders First
culturalNotes.content: When greeting a group, always greet the eldest person first. Younger people are expected to initiate greetings with elders.

practiceExercises.question: What is the Igbo word for 'Welcome'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Nnọọ' means 'Welcome'. 'Daalụ' is 'Thank you', 'Kedu' is 'How are you?', 'Ka ọ dị' is 'Goodbye'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Good morning' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ụtụtụ ọma' is 'Good morning'. 'Ehihie ọma' is afternoon, 'Mgbede ọma' is evening, 'Ka ọ dị' is goodbye.

practiceExercises.question: What is the appropriate response to 'Kedu?'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọ dị mma' means 'I am fine' and is the standard response.

practiceExercises.question: When should you use 'Mgbede ọma'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mgbede' means evening, so 'Mgbede ọma' is 'Good evening'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Thank you' in Igbo?

tips: Practice the morning greeting with your children every day to build routine.
Use 'Kedu?' as a cool way to check in with your diaspora crew.
In professional emails, you can open with 'Nnọọ' for a welcoming tone.
Greet your in-laws with 'Nnọọ' and 'Ụtụtụ ọma' to show respect.
Compare how 'Kedu?' is used in different Igbo dialects (e.g., 'Kedu' vs 'Kedu ka ị mere').
Practice aloud with a mirror
Listen to Igbo music to hear greetings in context
Use greetings with native speakers when you can

levels.title: Level 2: Basic Expressions
levels.description: Asking about well-being, responding 'Hello', 'How are you?', 'Where are you from?', 'What is your name?'
learningObjectives: Learn how to ask and answer 'Where are you from?'
Learn how to ask and answer 'What is your name?'

vocabulary.example: Ọ bụ gị ka m hụrụ?

grammarPoints.explanation: Yes/no questions often start with 'Ọ bụ...' or use rising intonation. 'Kedu' is used for open-ended questions.
Pronouns: m (I), ị (you), ọ (he/she), anyị (we), unu (you pl.), ha (they). They attach to verbs.

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Kedu ka ị mere?
dialogue.translation: How are you?

dialogue.speaker: Chinedu
dialogue.text: Ọ na-aga, daalụ. Kedu ka ị mere?
dialogue.translation: It's going, thank you. How are you?

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Ị si ebe?
dialogue.translation: I'm fine. Where are you from?

dialogue.speaker: Chinedu
dialogue.text: Esi m Enugu. Gịnị bụ aha gị?
dialogue.translation: I'm from Enugu. What is your name?

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Aha m bụ Ngozi. Ọ dị mma ịhụ gị!
dialogue.translation: My name is Ngozi. Nice to meet you!

dialogue.speaker: Chinedu
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma ịhụ gị, Ngozi.
dialogue.translation: Nice to meet you, Ngozi.

culturalNotes.title: Asking About Origin
culturalNotes.content: Asking 'Ị si ebe?' is common and not considered intrusive. It shows interest in a person's background and often leads to discussions about village, family, and dialect.

culturalNotes.title: Names and Meaning
culturalNotes.content: Igbo names often have meanings related to circumstances of birth, God, or family history. E.g., 'Chinedu' means 'God leads', 'Ngozi' means 'blessing'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Where are you from?' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ị si ebe?' means 'Where are you from?'.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Esi m Aba' mean?
Choose the correct response to 'Daalụ'.
How do you say 'My name is Emeka'?
What does 'Kedu ka ị mere?' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It is a more detailed way to ask 'How are you?'.

tips: Teach your children to ask relatives 'Ị si ebe?' to learn their roots.
Use 'Ị si ebe?' as an icebreaker with other young Nigerians.
In networking events, asking 'Ị si ebe?' can create personal connections.
Learn your partner's hometown and practice saying 'Esi m [town]' with pride.
Explore how different Igbo communities answer 'Ị si ebe?' (some say 'Esi m', others 'M si').
Repeat names and places out loud
Create flashcards for question words
Practice with a friend

levels.title: Level 3: Introducing Yourself
levels.description: Learn how to introduce yourself formally and informally.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Formal; for peers you can simply ask 'Aha gị?'

vocabulary.example: Ọ dị mma ịhụ gị, nwanne m.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Asking if someone is Igbo, Yoruba, etc.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Bụ' is used for identification (is/are). It follows the noun/pronoun.
To negate 'bụ', add '-ghị' to form 'bụghị'.

dialogue.speaker: Chika
dialogue.text: Nnọọ! Aha m bụ Chika. Gịnị bụ aha gị?
dialogue.translation: Welcome! My name is Chika. What is your name?

dialogue.speaker: Somto
dialogue.text: Nnọọ, Chika. Aha m bụ Somto.
dialogue.translation: Welcome, Chika. My name is Somto.

dialogue.speaker: Chika
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma ịhụ gị, Somto. Ị̀ bụ onye Aba?
dialogue.translation: Nice to meet you, Somto. Are you from Aba?

dialogue.speaker: Somto
dialogue.text: Mba, ọ bụghị. Esi m Owerri.
dialogue.translation: No, it's not. I'm from Owerri.

dialogue.speaker: Chika
dialogue.text: O Owerri! Ọ dị mma. Nwanne m.
dialogue.translation: Oh Owerri! That's nice. My friend.

culturalNotes.title: Introducing Elders
culturalNotes.content: When introducing an elder, use respectful terms like 'Deede' or 'Mazi' for men and 'Lolo' or 'Nne' for women, often before their name.

culturalNotes.title: Handshake
culturalNotes.content: A handshake is common when introducing yourself. For elders, you may bow slightly or support your right hand with your left as a sign of respect.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'My name is' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Aha m bụ' directly translates to 'My name is'.

practiceExercises.question: What is the meaning of 'Ọ dị mma ịhụ gị'?
How do you say 'No, it's not' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mba' is no, and 'ọ bụghị' means 'it is not'.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Nwanne m' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Nwanne' literally means sibling but is often used affectionately for close friends.

practiceExercises.question: Choose the correct way to ask 'Are you from Enugu?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ị̀ bụ onye Enugu?' means 'Are you a person of Enugu?' which is the common phrasing.

tips: Encourage your children to introduce themselves in Igbo at family gatherings.
Use 'Nwanne m' when introducing friends to make it more relatable.
Practice a formal self-introduction: 'Aha m bụ [First Last], m bụ onye [company].'
Learn to introduce your spouse: 'Nke a bụ di m / nwunye m, aha ya bụ...'.
Note that older generations might say 'Ọ fa m bụ' in some dialects.
Smile when introducing yourself
Remember names and use them
Repeat the other person's name to help remember

levels.title: Level 4: Empathy and Apologies
levels.description: The non-apology 'Sorry': 'Ndo', 'Biko'. Differentiate from 'Forgive me.'
learningObjectives: Learn to say 'Sorry' in different contexts

vocabulary.culturalNote: Expresses sympathy, not an apology for fault.
Used for polite requests and also to get attention.

vocabulary.example: Ọ dị m nwute maka mmejọ m.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Literal: 'It is pain to me' – used when you've wronged someone.

vocabulary.example: Biko, anụghị m ihe ị kwuru.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Polite way to ask someone to repeat.

vocabulary.example: Ọ dị mma, echegbula onwe gị.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Biko' is placed at the beginning or end of a sentence to make a request polite.
Use 'Ọ dị + noun' to express feelings. 'Ọ dị m nwute' (I am sorry), 'Ọ dị m ụtọ' (I am happy).
examples: Ọ dị m ụtọ ịhụ gị
Ọ dị m nwute maka akụkọ ahụ

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ m kpatara ihe ahụ. Ọ dị m nwute.
dialogue.translation: I caused that. I am sorry.

dialogue.speaker: Adaeze
dialogue.text: Ndo, ọ dị mma. Gbaghara m gị.
dialogue.translation: Sorry (empathy), it's okay. I forgive you.

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Daalụ, Adaeze. Echegbula m ọzọ.
dialogue.translation: Thank you, Adaeze. I won't worry again.

dialogue.speaker: Adaeze
dialogue.text: Biko, chefuo ya. Ka anyị gaa n'ihu.
dialogue.translation: Please, forget it. Let's move forward.

culturalNotes.title: Ndo vs. Sorry
culturalNotes.content: In Igbo culture, 'Ndo' is used for empathy (e.g., if someone is sick or had a loss). It is not an admission of guilt. For an apology when at fault, use 'Ọ dị m nwute' or 'Gbaghara m'.

culturalNotes.title: Communal Empathy
culturalNotes.content: When someone experiences hardship, it's common for many people to say 'Ndo' to show solidarity. The community shares the burden through words.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase would you use to express sympathy for someone's loss?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ndo' is used for empathy and sympathy, not for taking blame.

practiceExercises.question: How do you politely ask someone to repeat themselves?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Anụghị m, biko' means 'I didn't hear, please'.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Gbaghara m' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Gbaghara m' is a direct request for forgiveness.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Don't worry' in Igbo?
Which of the following is an apology for a mistake?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọ dị m nwute' expresses personal regret; 'Ndo' is for empathy.

tips: Teach children to say 'Ndo' when a friend is hurt, and 'Ọ dị m nwute' when they've done wrong.
Use 'Ndo' in DMs when someone vents, it's the Igbo equivalent of 'that sucks'.
In business, if a mistake occurs, 'Ọ dị m nwute maka nsogbu a' is professional and sincere.
Quickly say 'Gbaghara m' after disagreements to show humility and value the relationship.
Some areas use 'Ndo' more frequently; observe local usage to match the tone.
Tone of voice matters – 'Ndo' should sound gentle
Pair 'Biko' with a smile
Accept apologies with 'Ọ dị mma'

levels.title: Level 5: Basic Needs
levels.description: Asking for basic necessities and identifying them.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Literal: 'Hunger for food is biting me'.

vocabulary.example: Ọ bụ oge ụra, gaa n'akwa.
vocabulary.culturalNote: 'Akwa' can mean cloth or bed; context clarifies.
Home is central in Igbo culture.

vocabulary.example: Ọ bụ m, meghere m ụzọ!

vocabulary.culturalNote: Used to ask if someone has something.

grammarPoints.explanation: The verb 'chọrọ' (want/need) is used with the pronoun prefix: A chọrọ m (I want), Ị chọrọ (you want), Ọ chọrọ (he/she wants).
The verb 'nwere' means 'have'. It is used without a prefix: Ị nwere? (Do you have?), Enwere m (I have).
grammarPoints.pattern: Enwere m / Ị nwere / Ọ nwere + [noun]

dialogue.speaker: Obinna
dialogue.text: Nnọọ, nne. A chọrọ m mmiri, biko.
dialogue.translation: Welcome, mother. I want water, please.

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Nọrọ ebe a. M ga-ewetara gị mmiri.
dialogue.translation: Stay here. I will bring you water.

dialogue.speaker: Obinna
dialogue.text: Daalụ nne. Ụlọ a dị mma.
dialogue.translation: Thank you, mother. This house is nice.

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Ọ dịghị nsogbu. Ị chọrọ nri kwa?
dialogue.translation: No problem. Do you want food too?

dialogue.speaker: Obinna
dialogue.text: Ee, a chọrọ m nri, ma ọ bụrụ na ọ dị.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I want food, if there is.

culturalNotes.title: Hospitality
culturalNotes.content: Offering water or food to a visitor is mandatory in Igbo culture. Refusing an offer can be seen as rude, so always accept at least a small amount.

culturalNotes.title: Communal Sharing
culturalNotes.content: It is common to share food from a common bowl. Asking 'Ị nwere?' about food usually leads to sharing.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I want water' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'A chọrọ m mmiri' is 'I want water'.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ụra na-atụ m' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It literally means 'sleep is biting me' = I'm sleepy.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Do you have time?' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ị nwere oge?' is 'Do you have time?'

practiceExercises.question: What is the Igbo word for 'help'?
Choose the correct way to say 'There is no water'.
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọ dịghị mmiri' is the standard negation.

tips: Teach children to ask politely with 'Biko' when they need something.
Use 'A chọrọ m...' when ordering food at Nigerian restaurants.
In meetings, 'A chọrọ m ịkọwa...' is a good way to say 'I want to explain...'.
Offer your spouse water when they come home tired – 'Ị chọrọ mmiri?' goes a long way.
Different communities have slight variations: some say 'M chọrọ' instead of 'A chọrọ m'.
Use hand gestures when asking for items
Practice with objects around you
Listen for 'chọrọ' in conversations

levels.title: Level 6: Food and Ordering
levels.description: Ordering street food (Yam and Egg, Boli, Suya). Key phrases: 'I want small small,' 'Add pepper,' 'Pack for me take away.'
learningObjectives: Order food at a restaurant or stall

vocabulary.culturalNote: Yam is a staple; often eaten with egg or oil.

vocabulary.example: Ji na àkwá bụ nri ụtụtụ.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Yam and egg is a popular breakfast.
Boli is plantain roasted over charcoal, often with groundnut.

vocabulary.example: Suya na-ekpo ọkụ, ma ọ dị ụtọ.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Suya originated from Hausa but is loved across Nigeria.
Nigerians love pepper; 'small small' means a little.
Used when asking for extra portion.
Igbo often repeats words for emphasis or 'smallness'.

vocabulary.example: Biko, kechie m ya were laa.
A chọrọ m ji were laa.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Tinye' means 'put' or 'add'. Use it to give commands politely with 'Biko'.
Use 'obere' (small) or 'ntakịrị' (tiny) to indicate quantity. Repetition 'obere obere' means 'a little bit'.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa (Customer)
dialogue.text: Nnọọ. Ị nwere boli taa?
dialogue.translation: Hello. Do you have boli today?

dialogue.speaker: Onye nri (Food seller)
dialogue.text: Ee, enwere m boli ọhụrụ. Ole ka ị chọrọ?
dialogue.translation: Yes, I have fresh boli. How many do you want?

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa
dialogue.text: Nye m abụọ, ma tinye ose obere obere.
dialogue.translation: Give me two, but add pepper small small.

dialogue.speaker: Onye nri
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Ị chọrọ kechie were laa?
dialogue.translation: Okay. Do you want it wrapped to take away?

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa
dialogue.text: Ee, kechie m ya. Ego ole?
dialogue.translation: Yes, wrap it for me. How much?

dialogue.speaker: Onye nri
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ narị ise. Daalụ!
dialogue.translation: It's five hundred. Thank you!

culturalNotes.title: Street Food Culture
culturalNotes.content: In Nigerian cities, street food is vibrant. Boli, suya, and roasted corn are sold by roadside vendors. It's common to eat while walking or standing.

culturalNotes.title: Spice Preference
culturalNotes.content: When ordering, always specify your pepper level: 'obere obere' (little), 'ọtụtụ' (plenty), or 'enweghị ose' (no pepper).

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Yam and egg' in Igbo?
What does 'kechie m ya were laa' mean?
options: Wrap it for me to take away
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kechie' means wrap, 'were laa' means take away.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask for 'a little pepper'?
What is 'Suya'?
practiceExercises.explanation: Suya is skewered, spiced grilled meat, a popular Nigerian snack.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Add pepper' in Igbo?

tips: Take children to local Nigerian spots and practice ordering in Igbo.
Suya spots are great places to flex your Igbo – order 'Obere obere ose'.
If entertaining Nigerian clients, knowing food terms shows cultural competence.
Surprise your partner by making boli and saying 'Nke a bụ maka gị' (this is for you).
Learn local names: boli is called 'boli' across the South, but some areas have specific terms.
Start with 'Biko' when ordering
Smile at the seller – it's part of the exchange
Try to count money in Igbo

levels.title: Level 7: Directions and Locations
levels.description: Asking for directions: 'Where is...' and understanding 'Straight,' 'Turn at the big mango tree,' 'It is facing the road.'

vocabulary.example: Ụlọ ahịa dị nso ebe a.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'n' + location to mean 'at/in/on'. For specific sides, use 'n'aka ekpe/nri'.
Place the question word 'ebee' at the end of the sentence. Verb 'dị' (is located) is often used.

dialogue.speaker: Onye njem (Traveler)
dialogue.text: Biko, ụlọ ahịa dị ebee?
dialogue.translation: Please, where is the market?

dialogue.speaker: Onye obodo (Local)
dialogue.text: Gaa n'ihu, wee tụgharịa n'aka ekpe n'osisi mango.
dialogue.translation: Go straight, then turn left at the mango tree.

dialogue.speaker: Onye njem
dialogue.text: Ọ dị nso ebe a?
dialogue.translation: Is it near here?

dialogue.speaker: Onye obodo
dialogue.text: Ee, ihe dịka nkeji ise ije.
dialogue.translation: Yes, about five minutes walk.

dialogue.speaker: Onye njem
dialogue.text: Daalụ nke ukwuu!
dialogue.translation: Thank you very much!

dialogue.speaker: Onye obodo
dialogue.text: Ọ dịghị nsogbu. Jee nke ọma.
dialogue.translation: No problem. Go well.

culturalNotes.title: Landmark Directions
culturalNotes.content: In many Nigerian towns, directions are given using landmarks (big trees, churches, junctions) rather than street names. 'Tụgharịa n'osisi mango' (turn at the mango tree) is common.

culturalNotes.title: Helping Strangers
culturalNotes.content: It is culturally expected to assist someone asking for directions. Even if unsure, a person will often give some guidance rather than say 'I don't know'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Where is the market?' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ahịa dị ebee?' is the most common phrasing.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'N'aka ekpe' mean?
How do you say 'Go straight' in Igbo?
What does 'Nso' mean?
Which phrase would you use to say 'The house is behind the church'?

tips: When driving, teach kids direction words in Igbo: 'Anyị na-atụgharị n'aka ekpe'.
Use maps apps in Igbo – challenge yourself to navigate using only Igbo prompts.
If meeting a client at an unfamiliar location, ask 'Ụlọ ọrụ gị dị ebee?' to show effort.
When visiting your partner's village, ask for directions in Igbo – it will impress the elders.
Directional terms can vary; in some areas 'aka ekpe' is 'aka ịkpa'.
Use hand gestures when giving directions
Learn landmarks in your area
Practice with Google Maps in Igbo

levels.title: Level 8: Haggling at the Market
levels.description: Market negotiations: 'Reduce it for me,' 'Last price?' 'Na you be the boss.' 'How much?'
learningObjectives: Learn numbers and price negotiation phrases

vocabulary.culturalNote: Exclaim when price is too high.

vocabulary.example: Ọ bụ ngwụcha ego ị ga-ewe?
vocabulary.culturalNote: Asking if seller can go lower.
Asking for an extra item or discount.

grammarPoints.explanation: Igbo numbers: otu (1), abụọ (2), atọ (3), anọ (4), ise (5), isii (6), asaa (7), asatọ (8), itoolu (9), iri (10), narị (100), puku (1000).
Use the verb root for commands: 'Belata!' (Reduce!), 'Nara!' (Accept!). Add 'Biko' to soften.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa (Customer)
dialogue.text: Nnọọ, nwanne. Akwa a bụ ego ole?
dialogue.translation: Hello, my friend. How much is this cloth?

dialogue.speaker: Onye ere (Seller)
dialogue.text: Nke a bụ puku ise.
dialogue.translation: This is five thousand.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa
dialogue.text: Puku ise! Ọ dị ọnụ! Belata m ego.
dialogue.translation: Five thousand! It's expensive! Reduce it for me.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ere
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma, puku anọ ka m ga-ewe.
dialogue.translation: Okay, I will take four thousand.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa
dialogue.text: M ga-akwụ puku atọ, ọ bụ ngwụcha ego?
dialogue.translation: I will pay three thousand, is that the last price?

dialogue.speaker: Onye ere
dialogue.text: Nara puku atọ na narị ise. Ọ bụ ngwụcha.
dialogue.translation: Take three thousand five hundred. It's final.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa
dialogue.text: Ee, nara m. Daalụ!
dialogue.translation: Yes, I accept. Thank you!

culturalNotes.title: Haggling is Expected
culturalNotes.content: In Nigerian markets, haggling is not just accepted; it's expected. The initial price is always higher, and both parties enjoy the negotiation dance.

culturalNotes.title: Relationship Matters
culturalNotes.content: Calling the seller 'nwanne m' (my sibling) or 'ọgọ' (in-law) creates a friendly atmosphere that may lead to a better price.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'How much?' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ego ole?' is the standard way to ask the price.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Dị ọnụ' mean?
How do you ask for a reduction?
What does 'Ọ bụ ngwụcha ego?' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It asks if the price is final and non-negotiable.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I will pay three hundred'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'M ga-akwụ narị atọ' means 'I will pay three hundred'.

tips: Take your children to the market and let them try haggling in Igbo – it builds confidence.
Record a funny haggling skit in Igbo for social media – it's relatable content.
In procurement, knowing 'Belata ego' can help in informal negotiations with local suppliers.
When buying items for your spouse's family, haggling respectfully shows you value money.
Different markets have different haggling styles; observe first, then engage.
Start with a smile and a greeting
Never accept the first price
Be prepared to walk away

levels.title: Level 9: Polite Disengagement
levels.description: Polite disengagement: 'I am in a hurry,' 'Let me go small,' 'I will come back.'
learningObjectives: Learn how to politely end a conversation

vocabulary.example: Anọ m ọrụ, enweghị m oge.

Nọrọ nke ọma, anyị ga-ahụ echi.

grammarPoints.explanation: The prefix 'ga-' indicates future tense. 'M ga-ala' (I will go), 'Ị ga-abịa' (You will come).
Use the verb stem with 'biko' for polite requests or suggestions.

dialogue.speaker: Ezinne
dialogue.text: Nwanne m, ọ na-akụ m anya? Ọ bụ oge m ga-ala.
dialogue.translation: My friend, is it getting late? It's time for me to leave.

dialogue.speaker: Uche
dialogue.text: Ọ ga-ala ugbu a? Nọrọ obere oge!
dialogue.translation: Are you leaving now? Stay a little while!

dialogue.speaker: Ezinne
dialogue.text: Ọ dịghị m aka. Anọ m ọrụ n'ezie. M ga-ezitere gị ozi.

dialogue.speaker: Uche
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Gaa nke ọma, Ezinne. Ka emechaa.
dialogue.translation: Okay. Go well, Ezinne. See you later.

dialogue.speaker: Ezinne
dialogue.text: Nọrọ nke ọma. Anyị ga-ahụ echi.
dialogue.translation: Stay well. We'll see tomorrow.

culturalNotes.title: The Long Goodbye
culturalNotes.content: In Igbo culture, leaving a gathering is not abrupt. One announces intention to leave, is persuaded to stay, insists, and then exchanges blessings. This dance shows respect and affection.

culturalNotes.title: Promises to Return
culturalNotes.content: Even if you don't plan to return soon, saying 'M ga-alọta' (I will come back) or 'Anyị ga-ahụ' (We will see) maintains harmony.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am leaving' in Igbo?

levels.title: Level 11: Around the Home
levels.description: Vocabulary for the Nigerian household: Verandah, Parlour, 'Go and bring the kettle.'
learningObjectives: Learn 10 words for rooms and household items
Give and understand simple commands at home

vocabulary.culturalNote: The family home is central in Igbo culture.

vocabulary.example: Anyị na-anọdụ na veranda na mgbede.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Verandahs are common spaces for relaxation and receiving guests.
The parlour is where formal guests are received.
Electric kettle for boiling water for tea or instant drinks.
Traditional wooden plates are still used in villages.
Used for both cup and drinking glass.
Offering a chair to a visitor is mandatory.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Gaa' means 'go'. Used to give commands: 'Gaa weta' (go and bring).
'N'ime' means 'inside'. Use to specify location within a room or container.

dialogue.text: Ada, ị nọ ebee?
dialogue.translation: Ada, where are you?

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Anọ m na parlọ, nne.

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Ọ dị n'ime tebụl.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ahụrụ m ya. M ga-eweta ya ugbu a.
dialogue.translation: I see it. I will bring it now.

culturalNotes.title: The Verandah
culturalNotes.content: In traditional Igbo architecture, the verandah (mbara ihu ụlọ) is a semi-open space where family members relax, chat, and receive casual visitors. It's often cooler than indoors.

culturalNotes.title: Kitchen Etiquette
culturalNotes.content: The kitchen is typically the mother's domain. Children are often sent to fetch items or help with cooking, which teaches responsibility and respect.

levels.title: Level 12: Family and Kinship
levels.description: Specific terms for 'My mother’s sibling' vs. 'Father’s sibling.' Grandparents, Siblings. Cultural focus: Why you cannot date someone you call 'Sister.'

vocabulary.culturalNote: Also used as a respectful term for elder men.
Also a title of respect for women.

vocabulary.example: Nne nna m dị iri itoolu.
Nna nna m bụ onye ọrụ ugbo.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Gender context determines; often specified as nwoke/nwanyị.

vocabulary.example: Nwanne nne m si n'Ọstịrịa lọta.

grammarPoints.explanation: Possession is shown by placing the possessor after the noun, often with a tonal change or the word 'nke'.
Prefix 'nna' (father) or 'nne' (mother) to the base relative to indicate side of family.

dialogue.speaker: Chidi
dialogue.text: Onye bụ nwoke ahụ na-akpọ gị nwanne?
dialogue.translation: Who is that man calling you sibling?

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ nwanne nna m. Ọ si n'Enugwu Ukwu.
dialogue.translation: He is my father's brother. He is from Enugwu Ukwu.

dialogue.speaker: Chidi
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ nwanne nna gị. Ị nwere nwanne nne kwa?
dialogue.translation: He is your paternal uncle. Do you have a maternal aunt/uncle too?

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Ee, nwanne nne m bụ nwanyị. Ọ bi n'Ọnịcha.
dialogue.translation: Yes, my mother's sibling is female. She lives in Onitsha.

culturalNotes.title: Incest Taboo
culturalNotes.content: In Igbo culture, anyone you call 'nwanne' (sibling) – even if they are a cousin – is considered family. Dating or marrying such a person is strictly forbidden, as it is seen as incest.

culturalNotes.title: Respect for Elders
culturalNotes.content: Kinship terms are used even for non-relatives as a sign of respect. Elderly women are called 'nne' and men 'nna' regardless of blood relation.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'paternal grandmother' in Igbo?

practiceExercises.explanation: The term 'nwanne' implies siblinghood, making romantic relationships taboo.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'my father'?

practiceExercises.explanation: 'Nwanne' can mean sibling, cousin, or even a close friend, but implies family bond.

Understanding these terms helps you explain your family tree to others.

levels.title: Level 13: Body Parts
levels.description: Parts of the body – practical usage: 'My head is spinning' (illness), 'Open your mouth' (at the clinic).

vocabulary.culturalNote: Literal: 'My head is spinning' – means dizzy or headache.
Eye pain is common during Harmattan.
I have a fever (body is hot).
Can refer to entire arm or hand.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'na-egbu m mgbu' (is causing me pain) or 'na-afụ ụfụ' (hurts). 'Isi m na-awụ' (my head is spinning) is idiomatic.
Commands using body parts: 'Meghee anya gị' (Open your eyes), 'Mechie ọnụ gị' (Shut your mouth).

dialogue.speaker: Onye Ọrịa (Patient)
dialogue.text: Dọkịta, isi m na-awụ. Ahụ ọkụ na-agba m.
dialogue.translation: Doctor, my head is spinning. I have a fever.

dialogue.speaker: Dọkịta (Doctor)
dialogue.text: Meghee ọnụ gị, ka m hụ. Ọ na-afụ gị ụfụ ebe a?
dialogue.translation: Open your mouth, let me see. Does it hurt here?

dialogue.speaker: Onye Ọrịa
dialogue.text: Ee, ọ na-afụ m ụfụ mgbe m na-elo ilo.
dialogue.translation: Yes, it hurts when I swallow.

dialogue.speaker: Dọkịta
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ ọrịa akpịrị. Ị ga-aṅụ ọgwụ.
dialogue.translation: It's tonsillitis. You will take medicine.

dialogue.speaker: Onye Ọrịa
dialogue.text: Daalụ, dọkịta. M ga-eme ihe ị gwara m.
dialogue.translation: Thank you, doctor. I will do what you told me.

culturalNotes.title: Traditional Medicine
culturalNotes.content: Many Igbo people first consult traditional healers (dibia) before hospitals. Herbal remedies for ailments like stomach ache (afọ ọsịsa) are common.

culturalNotes.title: Palm Reading
culturalNotes.content: The palm (ọbụ́ aka) is considered significant; lines on the palm are believed to tell one's destiny.

levels.title: Level 14: Colours and Attire
levels.description: Describing clothing: 'I am wearing blue,' Ankara, George wrapper. Cultural focus: Colour symbolism in weddings/funerals.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Associated with mourning, but also formal wear.
Symbolizes purity; worn at weddings and title-taking.
Associated with chieftaincy, blood, and festivals.
Vibrant printed fabric, worn for celebrations.
Expensive, heavy brocade fabric; status symbol.

vocabulary.example: A na-eyi m uwe ọhụrụ taa.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Yi' is the verb for wearing clothes. It is conjugated with the pronoun prefix.
Colour adjectives follow the noun. Repetition of colour adds emphasis.

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Uwe gị mara mma taa! Àcha ole ka ọ bụ?
dialogue.translation: Your outfit is beautiful today! What colour is it?

dialogue.speaker: Adanna
dialogue.text: Daalụ. Ọ bụ anụnụ anụnụ. Ankara m hụrụ n'ahịa.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. It is blue. I bought the Ankara at the market.

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Ọ na-amasị m. Ị ga-eyi ya gaa agbamakwụkwọ?
dialogue.translation: I like it. Will you wear it to the wedding?

dialogue.speaker: Adanna
dialogue.text: Ee, mana aga m etinyekwa George n'úkwù.
dialogue.translation: Yes, but I will also add a George wrapper on my waist.

culturalNotes.title: Colour Symbolism
culturalNotes.content: At Igbo weddings, the couple and their families often wear matching Ankara prints (aso ebi). White (ọcha) symbolizes purity; red (uhie) is for titled men; black (oji) is for funerals and memorials.

culturalNotes.title: George Wrapper
culturalNotes.content: A George wrapper is a high-quality, heavy cotton or silk brocade fabric. It is a symbol of wealth and is often given as a gift during weddings, chieftaincy ceremonies, and funerals.

levels.title: Level 15: Morning Routine
levels.description: Morning routine – simple past tense: 'I bathed,' 'I ate,' 'I left the house.'

Morning devotion includes reading the Bible or Quran.
Sweeping the compound is often a child's chore.

grammarPoints.explanation: Add '-rV' suffix to the verb root, where V harmonizes with the vowel of the verb.

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Ị kpara ụlọ kwa?

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Jee nke ọma!
dialogue.translation: Okay. Go well!

culturalNotes.title: Morning Devotion
culturalNotes.content: Many Igbo Christian families start the day with morning devotion (ọmụmụ), including prayer, Bible reading, and hymns. It's a time for family bonding and spiritual nourishment.

culturalNotes.title: Chores
culturalNotes.content: Children are expected to help with morning chores like sweeping, washing dishes, or fetching water before school. It instills discipline and responsibility.

levels.title: Level 16: Unique Nigerian Scenarios
levels.description: Unique Nigerian situations: 'The light has gone' (power outage), 'Stop here!' (Okada), 'Hold your change.'

vocabulary.culturalNote: Common exclamation when power goes out.
Verb for starting generator or engine.
Borrowed from 'Okada Air', now generic for bike taxi.

grammarPoints.explanation: The suffix '-ọla' (or '-ela') indicates a completed action with present relevance. 'Apụọla' = has gone off.
'Kwụsị' means stop. Used as a command.

dialogue.speaker: Onye njem (Passenger)
dialogue.text: Okada! Okada!
dialogue.translation: Okada! Okada!

dialogue.speaker: Ọkwọ okada (Rider)
dialogue.text: Ebee ka ị na-aga?

dialogue.speaker: Onye njem
dialogue.text: Gaa ahịa. Ego ole?

dialogue.speaker: Ọkwọ okada
dialogue.text: Narị ise.

dialogue.text: Ee, kwụsị ebe a. Jide ego mgbanwe.
dialogue.translation: Yes, stop here. Keep the change.

culturalNotes.title: Okada Culture
culturalNotes.content: Okada (motorcycle taxis) are a common and fast means of transport in Nigerian cities. Passengers must wear helmets (where enforced) and negotiate the fare before the trip.

culturalNotes.title: Power Supply
culturalNotes.content: Unreliable electricity is a daily reality. 'Ọkụ apụọla' is heard frequently. Most homes and businesses own generators ('mkpụrụ') as backup.

culturalNotes.content: A large portion of Nigeria's economy is informal. Trading, artisan work, and small-scale farming provide livelihoods for millions. It's common for people to have multiple occupations.

culturalNotes.title: Apprenticeship

dialogue.translation: Let's meet this afternoon.

dialogue.speaker: Chuka
dialogue.text: Ole elekere?
dialogue.translation: What time?

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: N'ihe dịka elekere anọ.
dialogue.translation: Around 4 o'clock.

dialogue.speaker: Chuka
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Aga m abịa n'oge.
dialogue.translation: Okay. I will come on time.

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ nkwa. Ka anyị hụ.
dialogue.translation: It's a deal. See you.

culturalNotes.title: Nigerian Time
culturalNotes.content: 'Nigerian time' is a cultural concept where events often start later than scheduled. While punctuality is valued in formal settings, social gatherings have a flexible approach.

culturalNotes.title: Time Politeness
culturalNotes.content: Saying 'n'oge' (on time) is expected, but arriving 30 minutes late to a party is normal. For business, aim for 'Africa time' – about 15 minutes grace.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'right now' emphatically in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: Repetition of 'ugbu a' means 'now now' – immediately.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'n'obere oge' mean?
How do you ask 'What time is it?'
What time of day is 'n'ụtụtụ'?
If someone says 'Ka anyị hụ n'ehihie', when should you meet?

tips: Teach children to respect time: 'Bịa n'oge' is a good phrase to repeat.
When making plans with Nigerian friends, use 'N'ihe dịka...' to show cultural awareness.
In business, confirm appointments with 'Ọ bụ nkwa?' and aim to be punctual.
When your partner says 'Obere oge', don't expect them in 5 minutes!
Some Igbo speakers use 'ntakịrị oge' for 'small time'.
Always confirm appointments twice
Be specific: ask 'Ole elekere?'
Understand that 'ugbu a' can be relative

levels.title: Level 19: Weather
levels.description: Harmattan, Rainy season, Dry season. 'The sun is hot today,' 'I am cold.' Weather as social lubricant.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Exclamation: The sun is hot today!

vocabulary.example: Ikuku harmattan na-ekpo ọkụ ma na-ajụ oyi.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Dry, dusty wind from Sahara, Dec–Feb.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'na-' prefix with verbs of weather phenomena.
Use 'na-atụ m' (is biting me) for feeling cold/hot/hunger.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ihu igwe taa dị ụkọ! Anwụ ọkụ nke ukwuu.
dialogue.translation: The weather today is extreme! The sun is very hot.

dialogue.speaker: Chidi
dialogue.text: Ee, oge ọkọchị bụ. Oyi na-atụ m n'ụtụtụ.
dialogue.translation: Yes, it's dry season. I am cold in the mornings.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: N'ehihie, anwụ na-acha, ma n'abalị ọ dị mma.
dialogue.translation: In the afternoon, the sun shines, but at night it's nice.

dialogue.speaker: Chidi
dialogue.text: Anyị nwere olileanya mmiri ga-ezo n'oge na-adịghị anya.
dialogue.translation: We hope it will rain soon.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ee, ubi chọrọ mmiri.
dialogue.translation: Yes, the farms need water.

culturalNotes.title: Harmattan
culturalNotes.content: The Harmattan season brings dry, dusty air from the Sahara. Visibility reduces, skin cracks, and cold mornings contrast with hot afternoons. It's a common topic of conversation.

culturalNotes.title: Rain as Blessing
culturalNotes.content: Rain is seen as a blessing from God/Chineke. Farmers pray for rain, and the first rain of the season is celebrated.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'The sun is hot today'?
What does 'Oyi na-atụ m' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Oyi' is cold, 'na-atụ m' = is biting me.

practiceExercises.question: When is the rainy season in Nigeria?
practiceExercises.explanation: Oge mmiri is roughly April to October.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'Harmattan' known for?
practiceExercises.explanation: Harmattan brings cold mornings and dusty haze.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'It is raining'?

tips: Teach children to describe the weather each morning in Igbo.
Use weather phrases as conversation starters: 'Anwụ ọkụ taa, ọ bụ?'.
Commenting on the weather is a good icebreaker before meetings: 'Oge ọkọchị bụ'.
Check if your partner is feeling the cold: 'Oyi na-atụ gị?'.
In different regions, 'oge mmiri' may start earlier or later.
Check the weather forecast and describe it in Igbo
Use 'Anwụ ọkụ' when it's hot, 'Oyi na-atụ m' when cold
Notice how often Nigerians talk about Harmattan

levels.title: Level 20: Test 2
levels.description: Assessment: Tell a story about your day – waking up, leaving, a problem you solved, and returning home.
learningObjectives: Narrate a sequence of events in past tense

practiceExercises.question: You wake up and want to say 'I woke up early'. How do you say it?
options: A mụrụ m ụra n'isi ụtụtụ
practiceExercises.explanation: 'A mụrụ m ụra' = I woke up; 'n'isi ụtụtụ' = early morning.

practiceExercises.question: You want to say 'I swept the house'. Choose the correct past tense.
practiceExercises.explanation: 'A kwara m ụlọ' is past tense of sweep.

practiceExercises.question: You left home at 7am. How do you say 'I left at 7 o'clock'?
You took an okada. What do you tell the rider to stop?
The okada fare is 500 Naira. You give 1000 and say 'Keep the change'. How?
You meet a friend and ask about their profession. How do you ask?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Gịnị bụ ọrụ gị?' = What is your job?

practiceExercises.question: Your friend says they are a trader. How do you say 'I am a student'?
You experience a power outage. What do you exclaim?

tips: Have your child narrate their day in Igbo; prompt them with questions.
Record a voice note telling your daily story in Igbo – it's great practice.
Being able to narrate a sequence shows fluency; use it to describe your workday.
Share your day with your partner in Igbo; it strengthens both language and relationship.
Listen to how natives narrate events – they often use many 'na' connectors.
Use past tense consistently
Connect events with 'wee' (and then)
Mention time expressions
Include a problem and solution

levels.title: Level 21: Health and Well‑being
levels.description: Asking after someone’s health: 'How is your body?' 'I am tired,' 'I am coughing.' Empathy: 'Sorry for the pain.'

vocabulary.culturalNote: Often paired with specific illness names.
Can refer to both orthodox and traditional medicine.
Also used metaphorically for emotional pain.
Traditional healing is still widely respected.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Kedu + body part/health' to ask how someone is. 'Kedu ahụ ike gị?' is formal; 'Kedu?' is casual.
Use 'na-egbu m mgbu' for specific pain, or 'na-afụ ụfụ' for general hurt. 'Ike ọgwụgwụ na-agwụ m' expresses tiredness.

dialogue.speaker: Adaeze
dialogue.text: Nwanne, ị dịla mma? Kedu ahụ ike gị?
dialogue.translation: My friend, are you better? How is your health?

dialogue.speaker: Chibụike
dialogue.text: Ọ dịtụbeghị nke ọma. Ụkwara ka na-akụ m.
dialogue.translation: Not yet well. I still have a cough.

dialogue.speaker: Adaeze
dialogue.text: Ndo. Ị ṅụrụ ọgwụ?
dialogue.translation: Sorry. Did you take medicine?

dialogue.speaker: Chibụike
dialogue.text: Ee, a ṅụrụ m, mana ụkwara anaghị akwụsị.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I took it, but the cough won't stop.

dialogue.speaker: Adaeze
dialogue.text: Ndo, ọ ga-aka mma. Gaa hụ dọkịta ọzọ.
dialogue.translation: Sorry, it will get better. Go see the doctor again.

dialogue.speaker: Chibụike
dialogue.text: M ga-eme nke ahụ. Daalụ maka nchegbu gị.
dialogue.translation: I will do that. Thank you for your concern.

culturalNotes.title: Traditional Medicine
culturalNotes.content: Many Igbo people first consult a dibia (traditional healer) for ailments like malaria, stomach issues, or spiritual problems. Herbal remedies (ọgwụ ọdịnala) are common and often effective.

culturalNotes.title: Asking About Health
culturalNotes.content: It is normal and expected to ask detailed questions about someone's health. 'Kedu ahụ ike gị?' shows genuine care, not nosiness.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'How is your health?' formally?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kedu ahụ ike gị?' directly asks about health.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ụkwara na-akụ m' mean?
How do you say 'Take this medicine'?
What is the Igbo word for 'malaria'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ịba' is the common term for malaria.

practiceExercises.question: If someone says 'Ike ọgwụgwụ na-agwụ m', what do they feel?

tips: Teach children to ask 'Kedu ahụ ike gị?' when grandparents are ill – it shows respect.
Use 'Ịba' and 'Ụkwara' when texting friends who are sick – it's relatable.
If a colleague is unwell, 'Ndo, ahụ ike gị ka m na-ekpe ekpere' is a kind message.
Check on your spouse with 'Ị ike?' or 'Kedu ahụ ike gị taa?'.
Different areas have specific herbal names; e.g., 'ọgwụ ịba' for malaria medicine.
Practice asking and answering health questions
Learn common ailment names
Use 'Ndo' to show empathy

levels.title: Level 22: Personal Questions
levels.description: Answering personal questions ('Are you married?' 'How many children?' 'Why are you not fat?'). Polite deflections and humour.
learningObjectives: Learn question words (who, what, where, when, why, how)
Understand how to ask personal questions

vocabulary.example: Olee otú e si eme nke a?
Ị lụrụ nwunye? (to man) / Ị lụrụ di? (to woman)
Ọ bụ ihe nzuzo, agaghị m ekwu.

grammarPoints.explanation: Question words usually come first, followed by 'ka' and the rest of the sentence.
Use 'ọ bụ ihe nzuzo', 'achọghị m ịkọwa', or humour to avoid answering.
examples: Nri ka mma ikwu karịa afọ ole m dị.

dialogue.speaker: Nne (older woman)
dialogue.text: Nwa m nwanyị, ị lụrụ di?
dialogue.translation: My daughter, are you married?

dialogue.speaker: Ada (young woman)
dialogue.text: Mba, nne, amụbeghị m.
dialogue.translation: No, mother, I haven't married yet.

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Gịnị kpatara? Ihe na-egbo gị?
dialogue.translation: Why? What is preventing you?

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ ihe nzuzo, nne. Ọ bụ oge Chineke.
dialogue.translation: It's a secret, mother. It's God's time.

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Ehee, Chineke nwe ya. Ị ga-enye m ozi mgbe ọ bụla.
dialogue.translation: Alright, God's will. You will tell me whenever.

culturalNotes.title: Why Personal Questions Are Normal
culturalNotes.content: In Igbo culture, asking about marriage, children, and age is a sign of interest and belonging. It's not considered intrusive; it shows that you are seen as part of the community.

culturalNotes.title: Deflecting with Humour
culturalNotes.content: Humor is an accepted way to avoid answering. For example, if asked why you are not fat, you might say 'Ọ bụ ụdị ahụ Chineke nyere m' (It's the body God gave me) and laugh.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Who is that man?' in Igbo?
What is the Igbo phrase for 'It's a secret'?
How do you ask 'How many children do you have?'
What does 'Ajụla m ajụjụ ahụ' mean?
Which phrase asks for a reason?

tips: Teach children that answering personal questions from elders is respectful, but they can politely decline with 'Ọ bụ ihe nzuzo' if uncomfortable.
Expect these questions at family gatherings. Prepare a few deflection phrases.
In professional settings, avoid asking 'Ị lụrụ di/nwunye?' – it's too personal.
When visiting your partner's family, you will be asked these questions. Answer warmly or deflect with humour.
In some communities, 'Ị mụrụ ụmụ ole?' is asked even of newlyweds – it's a blessing, not pressure.
Memorise the question words
Practice answering personal questions in Igbo
Use 'Gịnị kpatara?' to ask why

levels.title: Level 23: Expressing Preferences
levels.description: Expressing likes/dislikes: 'I love this,' 'I hate pepper,' 'I don’t like wahala.'
learningObjectives: Learn verbs for liking, loving, hating
Express preferences about food, activities, people

vocabulary.culturalNote: Strong affection; used for people and deep passions.

vocabulary.example: Nke a bụ ọkacha mmasị m.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Borrowed from Hausa, used across Nigeria.
Used for food and also for good news.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Masị' is used with the impersonal 'ọ na-amasị m' = it pleases me. Subject is the thing liked.
Use 'a kpọrọ m asị' + noun. Strong hatred.

dialogue.speaker: Ezinne
dialogue.text: Nri a dị ụtọ! Ọ na-amasị gị?
dialogue.translation: This food is delicious! Do you like it?

dialogue.speaker: Somto
dialogue.text: Ee, ọ na-amasị m nke ukwuu. Ma a kpọrọ m ose asị.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I like it very much. But I hate pepper.

dialogue.speaker: Ezinne
dialogue.text: Ị kpọrọ ose asị! Kedu otu ị si eri nri Igbo?
dialogue.translation: You hate pepper! How do you eat Igbo food?

dialogue.speaker: Somto
dialogue.text: A na-eri m obere obere. Ọkacha mmasị m bụ ji na àkwá.
dialogue.translation: I eat small small. My favorite is yam and egg.

dialogue.speaker: Ezinne
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Achọghị m wahala n'ihi nri!
dialogue.translation: Okay. I don't want trouble because of food!

culturalNotes.title: Wahala – a Nigerian favourite
culturalNotes.content: The word 'wahala' (trouble) is used across Nigerian languages. 'Achọghị m wahala' is a common phrase meaning 'I don't want any stress'. It reflects a laid‑back attitude.

culturalNotes.title: Pepper Love/Hate
culturalNotes.content: Many Nigerians love pepper; those who don't are often teased. Saying 'A kpọrọ m ose asị' is almost a cultural confession.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I like this music'?
options: A hụrụ m egwu a n'anya
A kpọrọ m egwu a asị

practiceExercises.question: What does 'A kpọrọ m ụgha asị' mean?
How do you ask 'What is your favorite food?'
options: Gịnị bụ ọkacha mmasị nri gị?
Nri ole ka ị hụrụ n'anya?

practiceExercises.question: Which word means 'trouble' or 'stress'?
If someone says 'A hụrụ m gị n'anya', what do they feel?

tips: Ask children 'Ọ na-amasị gị?' about food, games, etc., to build vocabulary.
Use 'Achọghị m wahala' as a meme-worthy phrase – it's very relatable.
In negotiations, 'Achọghị m wahala' can be a light way to express a simple preference.
Learn your spouse's 'ọkacha mmasị' and 'ihe ọ kpọrọ asị' – it strengthens the bond.
Some prefer 'enweghị m mmasị' (I have no interest) instead of 'kpọrọ asị' for politeness.
Use 'masị' for liking, 'hụ n'anya' for loving people
Exaggerate with 'kpọrọ asị' for dramatic effect
Discuss your favorites with friends

levels.title: Level 24: Gossip and Secrets
levels.description: Small talk vocabulary: 'Did you hear?' 'Who told you?' 'Keep it between us.' Etiquette of secret‑keeping.

vocabulary.example: Debe nke a dịka ihe nzuzo.
Enwere m ike ịtụkwasị gị obi?
Ka nke a dịrị n'etiti anyị.
Anụla m na ọ lụrụ nwunye.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'na' to introduce a reported clause after verbs like 'sị' (say), 'nụ' (hear), 'chọpụta' (find out).
examples: Anụla m na ọ lụrụ nwunye
Ọ sịrị na ya agaghị abịa

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'debe' (keep) + noun. 'Ekwula onye ọ bụla' = don't tell anyone.

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Ị nụrụ akụkọ banyere Adanna?
dialogue.translation: Did you hear the news about Adanna?

dialogue.speaker: Nkechi
dialogue.text: Ee, anụla m! Ọ na-akwaga Canada?
dialogue.translation: Yes, I heard! She is moving to Canada?

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Ọnye gwara gị? Ekwela ka ọ gbasaa.
dialogue.translation: Who told you? Don't let it spread.

dialogue.speaker: Nkechi
dialogue.text: Ekwela m. Debe ya n'etiti anyị.
dialogue.translation: I won't. Keep it between us.

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Enwere m ike ịtụkwasị gị obi.
dialogue.translation: Okay. I can trust you.

culturalNotes.title: Gossip Etiquette
culturalNotes.content: Sharing news is common, but there is a clear code: some things are 'n'etiti anyị' (between us). Breaking that trust is a serious offense. It's also rude to spread unverified asịrị.

culturalNotes.title: Who told you?
culturalNotes.content: Asking 'Ọnye gwara gị?' is not necessarily accusatory; it's often genuine curiosity about the source of information.

practiceExercises.question: How do you start gossip with 'Did you hear?'
What does 'Debe ihe nzuzo a' mean?
How do you say 'Between us'?
What is 'asịrị'?
If someone says 'Ekwela onye ọ bụla', what do they want?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ekwela onye ọ bụla' = don't tell anyone.

tips: Teach children the difference between harmless news and secrets that must be kept.
Use 'n'etiti anyị' when sharing something private with a close friend.
In the workplace, avoid 'asịrị' – it can damage trust. Use 'akụkọ' for official news.
Secrets between spouses should be kept; 'debe ihe nzuzo' is a sacred vow.
In villages, news travels fast – 'ọnye gwara gị?' is a common response to surprising info.
Use 'Ị nụrụ?' to start a conversation
Promise secrecy with 'Ọ dịrị n'etiti anyị'
Verify before spreading asịrị

levels.title: Level 25: Emotions and Moods
levels.description: Emotions: happiness, anger, sadness, confusion. 'I am annoyed,' 'Don’t worry me,' 'I am just laughing.'

vocabulary.culturalNote: I am angry (anger is taking me).

vocabulary.example: Ekwela ka obi ọjọọ gbaa gị.
Nwee ndidi, ihe ga-akara gị mma.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Advice for those who are upset.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Obi' (heart) is used in many emotional expressions: 'obi ụtọ' (happy), 'obi ọjọọ' (bitter), 'obi ilu' (sour/pained).
Some emotions are expressed with impersonal verbs: 'iwe na-ewe m', 'ọṅụ na-atọ m', 'ụjọ na-atụ m'.

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Kedu ihe mere? I yiri onye iwe ji.
dialogue.translation: What happened? You look angry.

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Iwe na-ewe m n'ezie. Enyi m ekwughị m ozi.
dialogue.translation: I am really angry. My friend didn't tell me the news.

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Echegbula. Ọ ga-akọrọ gị ma emechaa.
dialogue.translation: Don't worry. He will tell you later.

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Mana ọ dị m mwute. Anyị bụ enyi.
dialogue.translation: But I am sad. We are friends.

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Nwee ndidi. Kpọọ ya jụọ ihe mere.
dialogue.translation: Be patient. Call him and ask what happened.

culturalNotes.title: Expressing Anger
culturalNotes.content: Direct confrontation is often avoided. 'Iwe na-ewe m' is a measured way to express anger without exploding. Elders may say 'Ewela iwe' (don't be angry) as a gentle rebuke.

culturalNotes.title: Laughter as a Mask
culturalNotes.content: Saying 'Ọ na-achị m ọchị' can mean you are genuinely laughing, or it can be a way to hide embarrassment or discomfort.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am happy'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Enwere m obi ụtọ' = I have a sweet heart (I am happy).

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Echegbula' mean?
How do you say 'I am angry'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Iwe na-ewe m' = anger is taking me.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'mgbagwoju anya'?
If someone says 'Nwee ndidi', what are they advising?

tips: Teach children to say 'Enwere m obi ụtọ' and 'Ọ dị m mwute' instead of crying.
Use 'Iwe na-ewe m' when you're frustrated – it's more expressive than English.
In meetings, 'Obi adịghị m mma maka mkpebi a' can diplomatically express disagreement.
Share your feelings: 'Ị mara, obi na-afụ m ụfụ taa' opens communication.
Some dialects use 'obi ilu' for bitterness; 'obi ọjọọ' is more standard.
Connect emotions to physical sensations
Use 'obi' phrases frequently
Ask 'Kedu ihe mere?' to show concern

levels.title: Level 26: Invitations
levels.description: Inviting to parties, weddings, burials. Stating location, date, and the phrase 'Your presence is requested.'

vocabulary.example: Anyị ga-asọpụrụ gị ma ị bịa.
Achọrọ m ịkpọ gị oriri nri abalị.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use the imperative 'bịa' (come) + event/place. For politeness, add 'biko' or use future tense 'ị ga-abịa'.
Use 'n'ụbọchị' for 'on the day', 'n'elekere' for time.

dialogue.speaker: Chinedu
dialogue.text: Achọrọ m ịkpọ gị n'agbamakwụkwọ m.
dialogue.translation: I want to invite you to my wedding.

dialogue.speaker: Adaeze
dialogue.text: Ee, ọ ga-amasị m ịbịa! Kedu ụbọchị?
dialogue.translation: Yes, I would love to come! What day?

dialogue.speaker: Chinedu
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ Satọde, ụbọchị iri abụọ na Machị.
dialogue.translation: It's Saturday, the 20th of March.

dialogue.speaker: Adaeze
dialogue.text: Ebee ka ọ ga-eme?
dialogue.translation: Where will it hold?

dialogue.speaker: Chinedu
dialogue.text: N'ogige Ọgọọ, n'elekere anọ.
dialogue.translation: At Ogọọ Hall, at 4 o'clock.

dialogue.speaker: Adaeze
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Aga m abịa sọpụrụ gị.
dialogue.translation: Okay. I will come to honour you.

culturalNotes.title: Wedding Invitations
culturalNotes.content: Igbo weddings are large, community events. Invitations are often extended verbally, and 'sọpụrụ anyị' (honour us) is a humble way to request attendance. Printed cards are for formal guests.

culturalNotes.title: Funeral Invitations
culturalNotes.content: Burials are announced in the community. Saying 'Bịa sọpụrụ nna anyị' (Come honour our father) is common. It's not considered morbid; it's a celebration of life.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I want to invite you'?
What is the Igbo word for 'wedding'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Agbamakwụkwọ' is the specific term for wedding.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask 'Where is the venue?'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ebee ka ọ ga-eme?' = Where will it happen?

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Sọpụrụ' mean in an invitation context?
How do you say 'on Saturday'?

tips: Teach children to extend invitations politely: 'Bịa n'ụlọ anyị'.
When throwing a party, use 'Achọrọ m ịkpọ gị' for a cool invite.
Formal business event? Use 'Enyere m gị ọrịrị' – it's very professional.
Invite your in-laws with 'Anyị ga-asọpụrụ unu ma unu bịa'.
Traditional weddings may have two dates: traditional and church. Clarify: 'Nke ọdịnala' vs 'nke ụka'.
Always specify date and time
Use 'sọpụrụ' for formal invitations
Verbally invite at least twice – it's polite

levels.title: Level 27: Accepting and Declining
levels.description: Saying 'Yes' enthusiastically. Saying 'No' without burning bridges: 'I will try,' 'God willing,' 'I am not around.'

vocabulary.example: Ọ dị m nwute, anọghị m n'obodo ụbọchị ahụ.
Ọ dị m nwute, enweghị m ike.
M ga-ahụ ma m ga-enwe oge.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Send regards when you can't attend.

grammarPoints.explanation: Future tense 'ga-' + verb expresses definite plan. 'M ga-agbalị' = I will try (weaker commitment).
Begin declines with 'ọ dị m nwute', end with 'n'oge ọzọ' or 'ekele'.
examples: Ọ dị m nwute, enweghị m ike.
Daalụ maka ọrịrị, mana anọghị m.

dialogue.speaker: Nnamdi
dialogue.text: A na-eme m oriri ncheta ọmụmụ echi. Ị ga-abịa?
dialogue.translation: I am having a birthday party tomorrow. Will you come?

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Ọ ga-amasị m ịbịa, mana enweghị m ike.
dialogue.translation: I would like to come, but I can't.

dialogue.speaker: Nnamdi
dialogue.text: Gịnị kpatara?
dialogue.translation: Why?

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Anọghị m n'obodo. M ga-alọta Sọnde.
dialogue.translation: I am not in town. I will return on Sunday.

dialogue.speaker: Nnamdi
dialogue.text: Ọ dị m nwute. N'oge ọzọ.
dialogue.translation: I am sorry. Another time.

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Ee, n'oge ọzọ. Keleere m ndị ọzọ.
dialogue.translation: Yes, another time. Greet the others for me.

culturalNotes.title: The Art of 'I will try'
culturalNotes.content: In Nigerian English and Igbo, 'M ga-agbalị' (I will try) often means 'I won't come' but said politely. It avoids outright refusal, saving face for both parties.

culturalNotes.title: God Willing
culturalNotes.content: Ọ bụ Chukwu (If God wills) is a common qualifier. It acknowledges that plans are not certain, and also reflects deep faith.

practiceExercises.question: How do you enthusiastically accept an invitation?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọ ga-amasị m' shows genuine desire to attend.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'M ga-agbalị' usually imply?
practiceExercises.explanation: It often means 'I'll try but likely won't make it'.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am sorry, I can't come'?
options: Ọ dị m nwute, enweghị m ike ịbịa
practiceExercises.explanation: This is a direct but polite decline.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Keleere m ha' mean in this context?
Which phrase expresses hope for a future meeting?

tips: Teach children to respond politely to invitations, even when declining.
Use 'M ga-agbalị' when you don't want to commit – it's universally understood.
In professional settings, be direct: 'Enweghị m ike ịbịa' is acceptable and clear.
When declining family events, always give a reason and send regards.
Some communities expect you to say 'Ọ bụ Chukwu' even for definite plans – it's humility.
Always thank the person for the invitation
If declining, give a brief reason
Promise to meet another time

levels.title: Level 28: Compliments
levels.description: 'You look beautiful,' 'You are shining!' 'I love your fit.' Cultural note: avoid praising babies/objects without 'God bless.'

vocabulary.culturalNote: Can be used for both men and women.
Compliment on skin tone, often seen as positive.

vocabulary.example: Ị bụ ọkacha mma n'ebe a.
Ị nwere àgwà ọma, nwanne m.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Blessing in response to a compliment.

grammarPoints.explanation: 'Mara' means 'know' but in this context it's an adjective. 'Ị mara mma' = you are beautiful.
It is polite to deflect or give thanks, often with a blessing.

dialogue.speaker: Adanna
dialogue.text: Chioma! Uwe gị na-egbu mara! Ebee ka ị zụtara ya?
dialogue.translation: Chioma! Your outfit is stunning! Where did you buy it?

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Daalụ, nwanne. A zụtara m ya n'ahịa Ariaria.
dialogue.translation: Thank you, my friend. I bought it at Ariaria market.

dialogue.speaker: Adanna
dialogue.text: Ọ dabara gị nke ọma. Ị na-acha ka ego!
dialogue.translation: It fits you perfectly. You are shining like money!

dialogue.speaker: Chioma
dialogue.text: Chineke gozie gị. Ị bụ ezigbo enyi.
dialogue.translation: God bless you. You are a good friend.

dialogue.speaker: Adanna
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ eziokwu. Ị ga-adi ogologo ndụ!
dialogue.translation: It's the truth. You will live long!

culturalNotes.title: Praising Babies and Objects
culturalNotes.content: It is considered dangerous to praise a baby or valuable object without adding 'Chineke gozie ya' (God bless it). Compliments alone are believed to attract envy or evil spirits.

culturalNotes.title: Skin Tone Compliments
culturalNotes.content: Ị na-acha' (you are fair) is a common compliment. Fair skin is historically associated with beauty and status, though modern perspectives are shifting.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'You are beautiful' to a woman?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ị mara mma' is gender-neutral and common.

practiceExercises.question: What should you add when complimenting a baby?
practiceExercises.explanation: Always ask God's blessing to ward off envy.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ị na-acha ka ego' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a compliment on glowing skin.

practiceExercises.question: How do you respond to a compliment?
What is the meaning of 'Ejiji gị dị egwu'?

tips: Teach children to bless babies: 'Chineke gozie nwa a'.
Use 'na-egbu mara' as a trendy compliment among friends.
Compliment colleagues on their work: 'Ọrụ gị dị mma nke ukwuu'.
Compliment your spouse daily – 'Ị mara mma' never gets old.
Some older folks may say 'Ị chaala' for 'you are fair'.
Always bless babies and new items
Accept compliments gracefully with 'Daalụ'
Return a blessing: 'Chineke gozie gị'

levels.title: Level 29: Condolences
levels.description: High‑stakes phrases: 'Be strong,' 'It is well,' 'Long life to you.'
learningObjectives: Learn vocabulary for death and mourning

vocabulary.example: Anụla m ọnwụ nne gị. Ndo.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Often weeks or months after death.

vocabulary.example: Ọ ga-aka mma n'oge na-adịghị anya.

vocabulary.word: Ka Chineke mee ka mkpụrụ obi ya zuru ike
vocabulary.pronunciation: kah chee-neh-keh meh kah m-kpoo-roo oh-bee yah zoo-roo ee-keh
vocabulary.example: Ka Chineke mee ka mkpụrụ obi ya zuru ike.

vocabulary.word: Ekwela ka obi gbaa gị mgba
vocabulary.translation: Don't let your heart wrestle you
vocabulary.pronunciation: eh-kweh-lah kah oh-bee gbah-ah gee m-gbah
vocabulary.example: Ekwela ka obi gbaa gị mgba.
Daalụ maka ndo gị, anyị nwere obi ụtọ maka nkwado unu.

grammarPoints.explanation: Begin with 'Ndo maka...' + loss. Then add encouragement: 'Gbaa ume', 'Ọ ga-aka mma'.
examples: Ndo maka ọnwụ nna gị. Gbaa ume.
Ndo. Ka Chineke mee ka mkpụrụ obi ya zuru ike.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Ị ga-adi ogologo ndụ' or 'Chineke ga-elekọta gị'.

dialogue.speaker: Chuka
dialogue.text: Ndo maka ọnwụ nne gị, Ada. Obi gbawara m mgbe anụrụ m.
dialogue.translation: Sorry for the death of your mother, Ada. My heart broke when I heard.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Daalụ, Chuka. Ọ bụ ọnwụ siri ike.
dialogue.translation: Thank you, Chuka. It was a hard death.

dialogue.speaker: Chuka
dialogue.text: Gbaa ume. Ọ ga-aka mma. Ị ga-adi ogologo ndụ.
dialogue.translation: Be strong. It will get better. You will live long.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ka Chineke mee ka mkpụrụ obi ya zuru ike. Anyị na-ekele unu maka nkwado unu.
dialogue.translation: May God rest her soul. We thank you all for your support.

culturalNotes.title: Mourning Period
culturalNotes.content: Traditional Igbo mourning can last weeks or months, marked by wearing black or white, shaving heads (for women), and avoiding festivities. Modern practices vary.

culturalNotes.title: Community Support
culturalNotes.content: Condolence visits are essential. People bring food, money, and stay with the bereaved. Saying 'Anyị nọnyeere gị' is more than words – it's a promise of presence.

practiceExercises.question: What is the most common word for offering condolences?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ndo' is the universal expression of sympathy.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Be strong' in Igbo?
What is an appropriate response to condolences?
practiceExercises.explanation: Thanking someone for their sympathy is proper.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ka Chineke mee ka mkpụrụ obi ya zuru ike' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It's a prayer for the deceased's soul.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase is a blessing for the living?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'You will live long' is a blessing to the bereaved.

tips: Teach children to say 'Ndo' when someone loses a loved one, and to be quiet and respectful.
If you don't know what to say, 'Ndo, gbaa ume' is always appropriate.
When a colleague loses a relative, send a message: 'Ndo. Anyị nọnyeere gị n'echiche.'
Support your spouse during loss – 'Ị ga-adi ogologo ndụ' is a powerful affirmation.
In some communities, 'Ọnwụ' is avoided; they say 'Ọ gakwuru ndị nna ya' (He has gone to his fathers).
Speak softly and sincerely
Offer practical help if possible
Prayers are always appreciated

levels.title: Level 30: Test 3
levels.description: Assessment: Role‑play – a friend is sad. Ask what’s wrong, listen, and offer appropriate comfort.
learningObjectives: Show empathy and ask about emotions

practiceExercises.question: Your friend looks sad. How do you ask 'What is wrong?' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kedu ihe mere?' = What happened? It shows concern.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend says 'Ọ dị m mwute' (I am sad). How do you show empathy?
Your friend reveals they are sick. What do you ask?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kedu ahụ ike gị?' = How is your health?

practiceExercises.question: Your friend says 'Iwe na-ewe m' (I am angry). What advice can you give?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Nwee ndidi' = Be patient – a calming response.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend lost a relative. What do you say?
Your friend thanks you for your support. How do you respond?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Anyị nọnyeere gị' = We are with you – reinforces solidarity.

practiceExercises.question: Your friend is worried about an exam. How do you say 'Don't worry'?
Your friend is crying. What comforting phrase can you use?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọ ga-aka mma' = It will be better – offers hope.

tips: Role‑play this scenario with your children to build emotional vocabulary.
Knowing how to comfort a friend in Igbo shows deep cultural connection.
In the workplace, offering support in Igbo can strengthen team bonds.
Practice comforting your partner – it builds intimacy and trust.
Observe how locals comfort each other; non‑verbal cues are as important as words.
Listen more than you speak
Use 'Ndo' freely
Offer practical help if possible
Stay with the person

levels.title: Level 31: Travel and Transport
levels.description: Shared taxi / bus: 'Driver, drop me at the junction,' 'Let me enter,' 'I am going to the main market.'
learningObjectives: Ask to be dropped at specific locations

vocabulary.culturalNote: General term; in context, means taxi/bus.

vocabulary.example: Ọkwọ ụgbọ, biko, kwụsị ebe a.
Nọdụ ala, anyị ga-apụ ugbu a.
Biko, kwụsị m na nkwụsị ahịa.
Ego ole si ebe a gaa Onịcha?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use verb roots directly: 'Kwụsị!', 'Bata!', 'Nọdụ ala!'. Add 'biko' for politeness.
Use 'aga m' + place to state where you are going. 'Ị na-aga?' asks direction.

dialogue.speaker: Onye njem
dialogue.text: Ọkwọ ụgbọ! Ụgbọ a na-aga Ahịa Ukwu?
dialogue.translation: Driver! Is this vehicle going to the Main Market?

dialogue.speaker: Ọkwọ ụgbọ
dialogue.text: Ee, bata. Anyị ga-ala ugbu a.
dialogue.translation: Yes, get in. We are leaving now.

dialogue.speaker: Onye njem
dialogue.text: Ego ole bụ ụgwọ?
dialogue.translation: How much is the fare?

dialogue.speaker: Ọkwọ ụgbọ
dialogue.text: Narị abụọ.
dialogue.translation: Two hundred.

dialogue.speaker: Onye njem
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Biko, kwụsị m n'ihu Ụlọ Akwụkwọ Central.
dialogue.translation: Okay. Please, drop me in front of Central School.

dialogue.speaker: Ọkwọ ụgbọ
dialogue.text: Aga m akwụsị gị ebe ahụ.
dialogue.translation: I will drop you there.

culturalNotes.title: Shared Transport
culturalNotes.content: Danfo (Lagos) or shared taxis (across the South) are common. Passengers board when seats are filled. Conductors often hang out the door calling 'Ahịa! Ahịa!'.

culturalNotes.title: Fare Negotiation
culturalNotes.content: In some shared taxis, fare is fixed per route. In others, you confirm before boarding. Always have small change.

practiceExercises.question: How do you ask the driver to drop you?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Kwụsị m ebe a' = Drop me here.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Bata' mean in a transport context?
How do you say 'I am going to the main market'?
What is a 'nkwụsị'?
How do you ask the fare?

tips: Teach children to say 'Biko, kwụsị m ebe a' when taking public transport.
Knowing transport phrases helps you navigate Nigerian cities independently.
If using ride-hailing apps, you can still greet the driver in Igbo – it's appreciated.
When travelling with your spouse's family, offer to pay: 'Aga m akwụ ụgwọ ụgbọ'.
In some areas, shared taxis are called 'kabu kabu'; conductors say 'Ngwa ngwa!' (Hurry!).
Always confirm the fare before boarding
Use 'biko' to soften commands
Listen for 'ọkwọ ụgbọ' to address the driver

levels.title: Level 32: At the Mechanic
levels.description: Basic car issues: 'The tyre is flat,' 'It is making noise,' 'How long will it take?'
learningObjectives: Learn vocabulary for car parts and problems
Ask about repair time and cost

vocabulary.example: Onye mezie ụgbọ nọ ebe a?
Ego mmezi ole ka ọ bụ?
Ị nwere ike ịdozie ya taa?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'mebiri emebi' (is damaged) or specific verbs in past tense: 'gbawara', 'tọgbọrọ'.
'Oge ole ka ọ ga-ewe?' = How long will it take? Use 'ga-ewe' for future.

dialogue.speaker: Onye nwe ụgbọ
dialogue.text: Nwanne, ụgbọala m na-eme ụda. Ị nwere ike ile anya?
dialogue.translation: Brother, my car is making noise. Can you look?

dialogue.speaker: Onye mezie
dialogue.text: Kedu ụdị ụda?
dialogue.translation: What kind of noise?

dialogue.speaker: Onye nwe ụgbọ
dialogue.text: Ụda siri ike si n'okpuru. Echere m na ọ bụ injin.
dialogue.translation: A loud noise from underneath. I think it's the engine.

dialogue.speaker: Onye mezie
dialogue.text: Ka m lee. Ehee, taya gị gbawara, injin adịghị mma.
dialogue.translation: Let me see. Aha, your tyre is flat, the engine is not good.

dialogue.speaker: Onye nwe ụgbọ
dialogue.text: Oge ole ka ọ ga-ewe idozi ya?
dialogue.translation: How long will it take to fix it?

dialogue.speaker: Onye mezie
dialogue.text: Ihe dịka elekere abụọ. Ego mmezi bụ puku ise.
dialogue.translation: About two hours. The repair cost is five thousand.

culturalNotes.title: Roadside Mechanics
culturalNotes.content: In Nigeria, roadside mechanics (aka 'naija mechanics') are skilled artisans who can fix cars with limited tools. They often specialise (e.g., auto-electrician, panel beater).

culturalNotes.title: Bargaining Repairs
culturalNotes.content: Repair costs are often negotiable. It's normal to ask 'Ị nwere ike ibelata?' (Can you reduce?).

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'My tyre is flat'?
What does 'Onye mezie ụgbọ' mean?
How do you ask 'How long will it take?'
What is the Igbo word for 'repair' (noun)?
If a mechanic says 'Ọ ga-ewe elekere abụọ', how long?

tips: When taking the car for repair, bring your child and explain in Igbo what the mechanic is doing.
Knowing basic car terms helps when your car breaks down in Nigeria – you won't be overcharged.
If you manage a fleet, learning these phrases helps communicate with local mechanics.
If your spouse's car has issues, offer to take it to the mechanic and use these phrases.
Different regions have local terms: some call mechanics 'mekaniki' (borrowed).
Describe the symptom, not the diagnosis
Always ask for cost before work begins
Be patient – repairs may take longer than quoted

levels.title: Level 33: Pharmacy and Health
levels.description: Symptoms: 'I have a fever,' 'I am vomiting,' 'Do you have something for malaria?'
learningObjectives: Ask for medication at a pharmacy

grammarPoints.explanation: Use '[symptom] na-egbu m' or '[symptom] na-agba m'.
Use 'Ị nwere ...?' (Do you have...?) or 'Nye m ...' (Give me...).

dialogue.speaker: Onye ọrịa
dialogue.text: Nnọọ. Ahụ ọkụ na-agba m, isi m na-egbu m mgbu.
dialogue.translation: Hello. I have a fever and a headache.

dialogue.speaker: Onye na-ere ọgwụ
dialogue.text: Ị nwere ụkwara ma ọ bụ ọgwụnwụ?
dialogue.translation: Do you have a cough or vomiting?

dialogue.speaker: Onye ọrịa
dialogue.text: Mba, ọ bụ naanị ahụ ọkụ na isi ọwụwa.
dialogue.translation: No, only fever and headache.

dialogue.speaker: Onye na-ere ọgwụ
dialogue.text: Ọ nwere ike ịbụ ịba. A ga-enye gị ọgwụ ịba na paracetamol.
dialogue.translation: It could be malaria. I will give you malaria medicine and paracetamol.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ọrịa
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Olee otú m ga-esi ṅụọ ya?
dialogue.translation: Okay. How do I take it?

dialogue.speaker: Onye na-ere ọgwụ
dialogue.text: Ṇụọ paracetamol otu abụọ ugboro atọ n'ụbọchị. Ọgwụ ịba a, otu ụbọchị.
dialogue.translation: Take paracetamol two tablets three times a day. This malaria medicine, once a day.

culturalNotes.title: Patent Medicine Vendors
culturalNotes.content: In many Nigerian communities, patent medicine stores (not always pharmacies) are the first point of care. They sell common drugs without prescription, but you should be cautious.

culturalNotes.title: Self-Medication
culturalNotes.content: It is common to self-diagnose malaria and buy ACTs. However, proper testing is advised.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I have a fever'?
What is 'ọgwụ ịba'?
How do you ask 'Do you have medicine for headache?'
What does 'ọgwụnwụ na-agbọ m' mean?
How do you ask for dosage instructions?
options: Olee otú m ga-esi ṅụọ ya?

tips: Teach children to describe symptoms: 'Ahụ ọkụ na-agba m', 'Afọ na-agwọ m'.
If you feel unwell while in Nigeria, go to a pharmacy and use these phrases.
Corporate travelers: keep a list of these phrases in case of health emergencies.
If your spouse is ill, you can pick up medicine: 'Aga m azụta ọgwụ ịba'.
Some drug names are English but widely understood: 'Panadol', 'ACT'.
Describe symptoms clearly
Ask for both generic and brand names
Confirm dosage before leaving

levels.title: Level 34: Present Continuous
levels.description: Present continuous: 'They are dancing,' 'It is raining,' 'The food is burning!'

vocabulary.example: Nna m na-akwọ ụgbọ ugbu a.
Nne m na-esi nri na kichin.

grammarPoints.explanation: Add 'na-' before the verb root. Pronoun prefixes change: 'a na-eri m' (I am eating), 'ọ na-eri' (he is eating).
Often the pronoun prefix is dropped: 'Na-eri m' instead of 'A na-eri m'. Common in casual speech.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Kedu ihe ị na-eme ugbu a?
dialogue.translation: What are you doing now?

dialogue.speaker: Chidi
dialogue.text: A na-esi m nri. Nri ji na àkwá.
dialogue.translation: I am cooking food. Yam and eggs.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ọ na-esi ísì ụtọ! Ụmụaka ebe a na-agba egwu.
dialogue.translation: It smells delicious! The children here are dancing.

dialogue.speaker: Chidi
dialogue.text: Chee ntị! Mmiri na-ezo. Bata ngwa ngwa.
dialogue.translation: Listen! It is raining. Come in quickly.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ee, anyị na-abata ugbu a.
dialogue.translation: Yes, we are coming in now.

culturalNotes.title: Time flexibility
culturalNotes.content: When someone says 'Ugbu a' (now), it may not mean immediately. 'Ugbu a ugbu a' is needed for urgency.

culturalNotes.title: Present continuous for future
culturalNotes.content: Igbo often uses present continuous to express near future: 'A na-aga m echi' (I am going tomorrow).

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I am eating'?
What does 'Mmiri na-ezo' mean?
How do you say 'They are dancing'?
Which phrase means 'The food is burning'?
How do you ask 'What are you doing?'
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ka ị na-eme' = that you are doing.

tips: Narrate your actions in Igbo throughout the day: 'A na-asa m efere', 'A na-akwọ m ụgbọ'.
Use present continuous to caption your Instagram stories: 'Na-eri nri n'Abuja'.
In meetings, describe ongoing projects: 'Anyị na-arụ ọrụ na nkwekọrịta ọhụrụ'.
Text your spouse: 'Kedu ihe ị na-eme?' to check in.
Listen for dropped prefixes: locals often say 'Na-eri m' not 'A na-eri m'.
Practice by describing your surroundings
Use 'ugbu a' to emphasize now
Note that the verb root does not change

levels.title: Level 35: Weekend and Past Events
levels.description: Past events: 'I went to the village,' 'We attended a naming ceremony.'

vocabulary.example: N'izuka gara aga, agara m ime obodo.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Many urban dwellers visit on weekends.

vocabulary.example: Anyị gara emume ịnwa nwanne m.
A hụrụ m enyi m ochie.
Anyị nọrọ n'ụlọ ma zụọ ike.

grammarPoints.explanation: Add -rV suffix to verb root, harmonizing vowels. Many common verbs have irregular forms: 'gaa' -> 'gara', 'nye' -> 'nyere'.
Use 'n'ụbọchị + day', 'n'afọ gara aga' (last year), 'n'izu ụka' (last week).

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Kedu ihe ị mere na ngwụcha izu ụka?
dialogue.translation: What did you do over the weekend?

dialogue.speaker: Chibụike
dialogue.text: Agara m ime obodo. Ọ bụ emume ịnwa nwanne m.
dialogue.translation: I went to the village. It was my sibling's naming ceremony.

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma! Ị hụrụ ezinụlọ gị niile?
dialogue.translation: Nice! Did you see all your family?

dialogue.speaker: Chibụike
dialogue.text: Ee, ha niile bịara. Anyị riri nri, ṅụrụ mmanya, gbakwara egwu.
dialogue.translation: Yes, they all came. We ate, drank, and danced.

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Nke ahụ dị ụtọ. Agara m naanị chọọchị ma zuru ike.
dialogue.translation: That's sweet. I only went to church and rested.

culturalNotes.title: Village Visits
culturalNotes.content: Many Igbo people who live in cities return to their ancestral villages ('ime obodo') on weekends, especially for ceremonies. It's a way to maintain connections to roots.

culturalNotes.title: Naming Ceremony
culturalNotes.content: A baby's naming ceremony ('ikpu aha') is held 8 days after birth. It involves prayers, giving the child a name, and celebration with kola nut and food.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'I went to the village'?
What is 'emume ịnwa'?
How do you ask 'What did you do last weekend?'
options: Kedu ihe ị na-eme na ngwụcha izu?
Kedu ihe ị mere na ngwụcha izu?
Kedu ihe ị ga-eme na ngwụcha izu?
Kedu ihe ị na-eme ugbu a?

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase means 'We ate and drank'?

Share your weekend highlights in Igbo on social media – it's unique and engaging.
