Memorize common irregular past verbs

levels.title: Level 36: Future Plans
levels.description: 'I will call you,' 'I will pay you on Friday,' 'We shall get there.' Cultural weight of promises.

vocabulary.example: M ga-eme ihe ị gwara m.
Ọ bụ nkwa, m ga-emezu ya.

grammarPoints.explanation: Add prefix 'ga-' before the verb root. Pronouns: 'm ga-' (I will), 'ị ga-' (you will), 'ọ ga-' (he/she will).
Use 'nkwa' (promise) + 'emezu' (fulfill). 'Ọ bụ nkwa' = It's a promise.
examples: Ọ bụ nkwa, aga m emezu ya

dialogue.speaker: Chuka
dialogue.text: Ị ga-abịa oriri m na Satọde?
dialogue.translation: Will you come to my party on Saturday?

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: Ee, m ga-abịa. Ọ bụ nkwa.
dialogue.translation: Yes, I will come. It's a promise.

dialogue.speaker: Chuka
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Ị ga-akpọ m tupu ị bịa?
dialogue.translation: Okay. Will you call me before you come?

dialogue.speaker: Ifeanyi
dialogue.text: M ga-akpọ gị na mgbede Fraịde.
dialogue.translation: I will call you on Friday evening.

dialogue.speaker: Chuka
dialogue.text: Daalụ. Anyị ga-erute n'oge.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. We will get there on time.

culturalNotes.title: Weight of Promises
culturalNotes.content: In Igbo culture, a promise (nkwa) is serious. Breaking a promise damages trust and reputation. Elders say 'Ekwela nkwa ị na-apụghị imezu' (Don't make a promise you cannot fulfill).

culturalNotes.title: 'We shall get there'
culturalNotes.content: 'Anyị ga-erute' is an expression of optimism, often used when facing difficulties. It implies faith that things will work out.

levels.title: Level 37: Instructions
levels.description: 'Cut it small small,' 'Add water gradually,' 'Turn it off.'

vocabulary.example: Bepụ anụ ahụ n'ime obere iberibe.
Gbakwunye nnu ma ọ dị mkpa.
Kpọọ mmiri tupu ị tinye tea.
Nụrụ ya ma ọ dị ụtọ.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use the verb root directly. Add 'biko' for politeness.
Use 'nke mbụ' (first), 'nke abụọ' (second), 'mgbe ahụ' (then), 'n'ikpeazụ' (finally).

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Ada, bịa zie m nri.
dialogue.translation: Ada, come and cook for me.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ee, nne. Gịnị ka m ga-eme?
dialogue.translation: Yes, mother. What should I do?

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Nke mbụ, bepụ ji ahụ n'ime obere iberibe.
dialogue.translation: First, cut the yam into small pieces.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. E bepụla m ya.
dialogue.translation: Okay. I have cut it.

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Mgbe ahụ, tinye ya n'ite, gbakwunye mmiri nwayọọ nwayọọ.
dialogue.translation: Then, put it in the pot, add water gradually.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: M ga-eme nke ahụ. Ọ ga-esi ruo mgbe?
dialogue.translation: I will do that. How long will it cook?

dialogue.speaker: Nne
dialogue.text: Chere ihe dịka nkeji iri, gbachie ọkụ, nụrụ ya.
dialogue.translation: Wait about ten minutes, turn off the heat, taste it.

culturalNotes.title: Learning by Doing
culturalNotes.content: Cooking instructions are often given orally, with daughters learning from mothers. 'Nwayọọ nwayọọ' (slowly slowly) is a key phrase – patience is valued.

culturalNotes.title: Repetition for Emphasis
culturalNotes.content: Repeating words like 'nwayọọ nwayọọ', 'obere obere' (small small) is a common Igbo linguistic feature to indicate gradual action.

What does 'Gbakwunye mmiri' mean?

tips: Give your children cooking instructions in Igbo – it's practical language learning.
Follow Nigerian recipes online and translate the instructions into Igbo.
In technical training, use 'Nke mbụ, nke abụọ, nke atọ' to structure instructions.
Cooking together? Use Igbo instructions – it's fun and intimate.

Use repetition for gradual actions
Break instructions into numbered steps

levels.title: Level 38: Advice
levels.description: 'Don’t touch that,' 'Be careful,' 'If I were you...'

vocabulary.word: Ọ bụrụ na m bụ gị
vocabulary.pronunciation: aw boo-roo nah m boo gee
vocabulary.example: Ọ bụrụ na m bụ gị, aga m ajụ.
Ọ ka mma ị nọrọ n'ụlọ.
Ekwela ka ụmụaka gwuo egwu n'okporo ụzọ.
Nke ahụ bụ ihe ize ndụ.
Chee echiche tupu ị mee ihe.

grammarPoints.explanation: Add '-la' suffix to verb root to form prohibitions: 'emetụ + la' = don't touch.
Use 'ọ bụrụ na' (if) + past subjunctive. 'Ọ bụrụ na m bụ gị' = if I were you.
examples: Ọ bụrụ na m bụ gị, m ga-...
Ọ bụrụ na ọ bịara, anyị ga-ahụ

dialogue.speaker: Nna
dialogue.text: Nwa m nwoke, emetụla igbe ọkụ ahụ.
dialogue.translation: My son, don't touch that electrical box.

dialogue.speaker: Nwa
dialogue.text: Gịnị kpatara, nna?
dialogue.translation: Why, father?

dialogue.speaker: Nna
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ ihe ize ndụ. Ọ nwere ike igbu gị.
dialogue.translation: It's dangerous. It can kill you.

dialogue.speaker: Nwa
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. M ga-anọ ebe a.
dialogue.translation: Okay. I will stay here.

dialogue.speaker: Nna
dialogue.text: Ọ ka mma. Ọ bụrụ na m bụ gị, aga m egwu egwu n'èzí.
dialogue.translation: That's better. If I were you, I would play outside.

culturalNotes.title: Advice from Elders
culturalNotes.content: Advice from parents and elders is highly valued. 'Ị kwesịrị' (you should) from an elder is not just a suggestion – it carries weight and is expected to be followed.

culturalNotes.title: Indirect Advice
culturalNotes.content: Sometimes advice is given through proverbs rather than direct commands. 'Onye amaghị ebe mmiri si bata, ọ gaghị ama ebe ọ ga-esi pụta' (One who doesn't know where rain entered won't know exit).

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Don't touch'?

practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọ bụrụ na m bụ gị' = if I were you.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase gives strong advice?

Use negative imperatives for warnings

Always thank someone for advice

levels.title: Level 39: Formal Language
levels.description: Code‑switching: speaking 'High' Nigerian English / formal vernacular in professional settings.

vocabulary.example: Ọ bụ ihe ùgwù ịnọ ebe a taa.
N'aha ụlọ ọrụ anyị, ana m ekele gị.
Enwere m olileanya maka oghere ọrụ.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use titles like 'Maazị' (Mr.), 'Lọọlọ' (Mrs./Madam), 'Deede' (Elder). Use plural 'unu' even for one person as respect.
Begin with 'Ọ bụ ihe ùgwù...', 'Ekene m...', 'N'aha...'.
examples: Ọ bụ ihe ùgwù ịnọ ebe a

dialogue.speaker: Onye isi oche
dialogue.text: Ekene m na-ezitere unu niile. Ọ bụ ihe ùgwù ịnọ ebe a taa.
dialogue.translation: I bring greetings to you all. It is an honour to be here today.

dialogue.speaker: Ndị bịara
dialogue.text: Daalụ. Anyị nwere obi ụtọ ịnọ.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. We are happy to be present.

dialogue.speaker: Onye isi oche
dialogue.text: N'aha ụlọ ọrụ anyị, ana m ekele unu maka nkwado unu.
dialogue.translation: On behalf of our organization, I thank you for your support.

dialogue.speaker: Ndị bịara
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ anyị na-ekele. Anyị ga-aga n'ihu ịkwado gị.
dialogue.translation: We are the ones to thank. We will continue to support you.

culturalNotes.title: Code‑switching
culturalNotes.content: In formal settings (meetings, speeches, church), Igbo speakers often use 'High' Igbo – more elaborate, with proverbs and respectful address. Code‑switching with English is also common: 'I want to thank you for your nkwado'.

culturalNotes.title: Proverbs in Formal Speech
culturalNotes.content: Elders and orators use proverbs to convey wisdom. A speech without a proverb is considered bare. Example: 'Onye ji onye n'azụ, ka ọ na-aga' (He who carries someone on his back decides the direction).

In interviews or formal events, start with 'Ọ bụ ihe ùgwù' – it makes a strong impression.
Master formal openings and closings; they are essential for Nigerian business culture.

Chieftaincy titles (e.g., 'Ichiedu', 'Onowu') should be used if applicable.
Observe how elders speak in public
Use proverbs sparingly but correctly

levels.title: Level 41: Igbo Proverbs
levels.description: 'A child who washes his hands...' and 'The sun that shines...' – context, not just memorisation.

vocabulary.example: Ọ ma ilu Igbo nke ọma.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Proverbs are the palm oil with which words are eaten.

vocabulary.word: Onye akwụghị aka ya, nri adịghị ya n'ọnụ
vocabulary.translation: He who does not wash his hands does not eat with elders
vocabulary.pronunciation: aw-nyeh ah-kwoo-hee ah-kah yah, n-ree ah-dee-hee yah n or-noo
vocabulary.example: Ọ bụ eziokwu: onye akwụghị aka ya, nri adịghị ya n'ọnụ.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Respect and preparation are required to participate in important matters.

vocabulary.word: Anwụ na-awa n'ụra, ọ dịghị onye ma ebe ọ ga-ada
vocabulary.translation: The sun rises from its sleep, no one knows where it will set
vocabulary.pronunciation: ah-nwoo nah-wah-wah n oo-rah, aw dee-hee aw-nyeh mah eh-beh aw gah ah-dah
vocabulary.culturalNote: Life is uncertain; the future is unknown.

vocabulary.word: Onye ji onye n'azụ, ka ọ na-aga
vocabulary.translation: He who carries someone on his back decides the direction
vocabulary.pronunciation: aw-nyeh jee aw-nyeh n ah-zoo, kah aw nah-ah-gah
vocabulary.culturalNote: The one in charge leads; often said of leaders.

vocabulary.word: Eze enweghị ihe ọ na-eri, ụmụ ya enweghị ihe ha na-eri
vocabulary.translation: If the king has nothing to eat, his children have nothing to eat
vocabulary.pronunciation: eh-zeh eh-n-weh-hee ee-heh aw neh-ree, oo-moo yah eh-n-weh-hee ee-heh ha nah-ree
vocabulary.culturalNote: The leader's welfare affects the whole community.

vocabulary.word: Otu mkpịsị aka adịghị ebu ihe elu
vocabulary.translation: One finger cannot lift a load
vocabulary.pronunciation: oh-too m-kpee-see ah-kah ah-dee-hee eh-boo ee-heh eh-loo
vocabulary.culturalNote: Unity is strength; teamwork is essential.

vocabulary.word: Agadi nwanyi tara ogili, ọ matala na ọ ga-agba ara
vocabulary.translation: The old woman who chewed the bitter leaf knew she would be mad
vocabulary.pronunciation: ah-gah-dee n-wah-nyee tah-rah oh-gee-lee, aw mah-tah-lah nah aw gah ah-gbah ah-rah
vocabulary.culturalNote: Actions have consequences; you knew the risks.
Where there is determination, divine help follows.

grammarPoints.explanation: Proverbs often follow a 'if/then' structure or a simple statement with metaphorical meaning. Many begin with 'onye' (whoever) or state a general truth.
Proverbs are introduced with phrases like 'Dịka ilu siri kwuo' (as the proverb says) or 'Ilu Igbo na-ekwu na...' (Igbo proverb says that...).
examples: Dịka ilu siri kwuo, onye akwụghị aka ya...
Ilu Igbo na-ekwu na eze enweghị ihe ọ na-eri...

dialogue.speaker: Nna ochie
dialogue.text: Nwa m, ị matala na ị ga-alụ nwanyị. Cheta ilu: 'Onye akwụghị aka ya, nri adịghị ya n'ọnụ.'
dialogue.translation: My child, you know you will marry. Remember the proverb: 'He who does not wash his hands does not eat with elders.'

dialogue.speaker: Nwa okorobịa
dialogue.text: Nna, a ghọtara m. Ọ pụtara na m ga-akwanyere ndị ochie ùgwù.
dialogue.translation: Father, I understand. It means I must respect elders.

dialogue.speaker: Nna ochie
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ ya. Ọzọkwa, 'otu mkpịsị aka adịghị ebu ihe elu' – ị chọrọ nkwado ezinụlọ.
dialogue.translation: Yes. Also, 'one finger cannot lift a load' – you need family support.

dialogue.speaker: Nwa okorobịa
dialogue.text: Ee, nna. Aga m echeta ilu ndị a mgbe niile.
dialogue.translation: Yes, father. I will always remember these proverbs.

culturalNotes.title: Proverbs as Wisdom
culturalNotes.content: In Igbo culture, a person who speaks with proverbs is regarded as wise and eloquent. Elders use ilu to teach, warn, and advise without direct confrontation.

culturalNotes.title: Context is Key
culturalNotes.content: Using a proverb in the wrong context can be embarrassing. It's better to listen and learn before attempting to use them. Proverbs are not just phrases; they carry deep cultural meaning.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Onye akwụghị aka ya, nri adịghị ya n'ọnụ' mean?

practiceExercises.explanation: The proverb teaches that one must earn the right to be in important discussions through respect and preparation.

practiceExercises.question: Which proverb emphasizes teamwork?
options: Otu mkpịsị aka adịghị ebu ihe elu
practiceExercises.explanation: 'One finger cannot lift a load' means we need each other.

practiceExercises.question: How do you introduce a proverb in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Dịka ilu siri kwuo' = as the proverb says.

practiceExercises.question: What is the meaning of 'Anwụ na-awa n'ụra, ọ dịghị onye ma ebe ọ ga-ada'?
practiceExercises.explanation: No one knows where the sun will set – the future is unknown.

practiceExercises.question: When would you use 'Onye kwe, Chineke ekwe'?
options: When someone is determined and needs encouragement
practiceExercises.explanation: It means 'if one agrees, God agrees' – used to encourage effort and faith.

tips: Teach children one proverb per week and discuss its meaning at dinner.
Learn proverbs to impress elders and connect with your heritage.
Using a well-placed proverb in a business meeting can show deep cultural understanding.

levels.title: Level 42: Making Complaints
levels.description: Express dissatisfaction without shouting: 'This thing is not correct,' 'I paid for service but...' Assertive, not aggressive.

vocabulary.translation: This is not complete / not right
vocabulary.example: Ihe a ezughị ezu, akwụghị m ego zuru ezu?
vocabulary.culturalNote: Polite way to point out an error.

vocabulary.word: Ọ bụghị ihe m tụrụ anya
vocabulary.translation: It is not what I expected
vocabulary.pronunciation: aw boo-hee ee-heh m too-roo ah-nyah
vocabulary.example: Ọrụ a bụghị ihe m tụrụ anya.

vocabulary.word: Emeghị ihe e kwere ná nkwa
vocabulary.translation: You did not do what was promised
vocabulary.pronunciation: eh-meh-hee ee-heh eh kweh-reh n n-kwah
vocabulary.example: Emeghị ihe e kwere ná nkwa maka mmezi ụgbọala m.
Enwere m nsogbu na ngwaahịa a.
Anaghị m enwe afọ ojuju maka ọrụ unu.
Ọ bụ njehie, biko dezie ya.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use '-ghi' suffix to negate verbs. 'Emeghi' = did not do. 'Ezughị' = not enough/complete.
Start with 'Biko', 'Ọ dị m nwute', 'Enwere m nsogbu' to soften the complaint.
examples: Ọ dị m nwute, ma nke a ezughị ezu.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa
dialogue.text: Ọ dị m nwute, mana enwere m nsogbu na nri m nyere iwu.
dialogue.translation: I am sorry, but I have a problem with the food I ordered.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ọrụ
dialogue.text: Gịnị bụ nsogbu ahụ, nwanne?
dialogue.translation: What is the problem, friend?

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa
dialogue.text: Ọ bụghị ihe m tụrụ anya. Enwere m ose n'ime ya, ma agwara m ha ka ha ghara itinye ose.
dialogue.translation: It is not what I expected. There is pepper in it, but I told them not to put pepper.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ọrụ
dialogue.text: Ọ dị m nwute maka njehie ahụ. M ga-emezigharị ya ozugbo.
dialogue.translation: I am sorry for that mistake. I will correct it immediately.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ahịa
dialogue.text: Daalụ. Anaghị m achọ nweghachi ego, naanị ka e dozie ya.
dialogue.translation: Thank you. I don't want a refund, just to have it fixed.

culturalNotes.title: Saving Face
culturalNotes.content: Direct confrontation is avoided. Even when complaining, one should start with an apology or polite phrase. Shouting or insulting damages relationships.

culturalNotes.title: Assertiveness vs Aggression
culturalNotes.content: Being assertive ('Ị ga-emezigharị ya') is acceptable when calm. Aggression ('Ị ghọgburu m!') is seen as rude and may lead to defensive refusal.

practiceExercises.question: How do you politely say 'I am not satisfied'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Anaghị m enwe afọ ojuju' is formal and polite.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ọ bụ njehie' mean?

options: Gịnị mere i ji mee nke a?
practiceExercises.explanation: Starting with 'I am sorry' shows respect.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'You must correct it immediately'?

tips: Teach children to complain politely: 'Ọ dị m nwute, mana enwere m nsogbu.'
When returning an item, use 'Enwere m nsogbu na nke a' – it's effective and calm.
In customer service, start with 'Anaghị m enwe afọ ojuju' – it's professional.

Stay calm and polite

levels.title: Level 43: Igbo Slang and Youth Speak
levels.description: Current youth slang: 'Ajebo,' 'Omo,' 'Gbese,' 'Jaiye.' Warning: when not to use these.

vocabulary.example: Ọ bụ ajebo, o nweghị ike ịghọta anyị.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Originally Yoruba, now pan-Nigerian. Can be derogatory or teasing.
Slang for money, popular in music.

vocabulary.example: Nke a bụ shenk, ọ bụghị ezigbo.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Pidgin, but widely used in Igbo slang.

grammarPoints.explanation: Slang is often mixed with English or Pidgin. It is informal and should be avoided with elders or in formal settings.
Young people use slang to signal in-group membership. It evolves quickly; what is cool today may be outdated tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: Emeka
dialogue.text: Omo, kedu? Ị nọ ebe a?
dialogue.translation: Dude, what's up? Are you here?

dialogue.speaker: Chibụike
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma, mana enweghị m gbese. Ajebo ka ị bụ?
dialogue.translation: I'm good, but I have no cash. Are you an ajebo?

dialogue.speaker: Emeka
dialogue.text: Mba, mba. Anyị ga-ajaiye na Sọnde, ị bịa?
dialogue.translation: No, no. We will party on Sunday, are you coming?

dialogue.speaker: Chibụike
dialogue.text: Ọ bụrụ na enwere m gbese, m ga-abịa. Ma nwatakịrị a kọnkọ nke ukwuu, gị onwe gị!
dialogue.translation: If I have money, I will come. But this child is very stubborn, you yourself!

culturalNotes.title: When NOT to use slang
culturalNotes.content: Never use slang with elders, in church, in formal meetings, or with strangers. It can be seen as disrespectful or immature.

culturalNotes.title: Slang is fluid
culturalNotes.content: New slang emerges from Nollywood, music, and social media. What is listed here may change; always observe current usage.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ajebo' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ajebo' refers to someone from an upper-class background.

practiceExercises.question: Which of these is slang for 'money'?
How would you address a friend casually?
In what situation should you AVOID using slang?
What does 'Jaiye' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Jaiye' means to have fun or party.

tips: Don't be alarmed when your teenager uses slang – it's part of peer culture. Teach them when it's appropriate.
Slang connects you to your peers, but know when to switch to standard Igbo.
Avoid slang in professional environments entirely. Use standard Igbo.
You and your spouse can use slang playfully, but not in front of elders.
Slang varies by region and age group; ask young people what's current.
Listen to Nigerian hip-hop to catch new slang
Use slang only with close friends
When in doubt, use standard Igbo

levels.title: Level 44: Humor
levels.description: Simple jokes, wordplay, and how to laugh at yourself.

vocabulary.example: Ekwela ka ịkpa ọchị gị meghee ọnya.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Don't let your jokes cause pain.

vocabulary.example: Ọ na-akpọ m onye nzuzu, ma ọ bụ ọchị.
Okwu ya dị ilu, ọ bụghị ọchị.
vocabulary.culturalNote: Sarcasm is sometimes used but can offend.

vocabulary.example: Biko, mee ka m chịa ọchị.

grammarPoints.explanation: Igbo jokes often follow a call-response or question-answer format. Puns rely on words with multiple meanings.
examples: Gịnị ka onye Igbo na-eri ma ọ dịghị ọnụ? – Ji! (What does an Igbo person eat that has no mouth? – Yam!)
Onye isi ụlọ akwụkwọ gwara ụmụaka: 'Ọ bụrụ na m bụ nnụnụ...' – 'Gịnị mere ị ga-eji buru ibu?'

grammarPoints.explanation: Laughing at oneself is admired. Phrases like 'A bụ m onye nzuzu' (I am foolish) can be used humorously.
examples: A bụ m onye nzuzu maka ime nke ahụ!
Ọ bụ m kpatara ya, ọ bụ egwuregwu.

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Kedu ihe mere i ji abịa n'oge?
dialogue.translation: Why are you late?

dialogue.speaker: Chidi
dialogue.text: Ụgbọala m amaliteghị. A bụ m onye nzuzu, echefuru m ịgbanye ya!
dialogue.translation: My car didn't start. I am foolish, I forgot to turn it on!

dialogue.speaker: Ada
dialogue.text: Ọchị na-achị m! Ị ga-aka mma.
dialogue.translation: I am laughing! You are something else.

dialogue.speaker: Chidi
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ egwuregwu, mana eziokwu bụ na m hụrụrụ n'ụra.
dialogue.translation: It's a joke, but the truth is I overslept.

culturalNotes.title: Laughter is Healing
culturalNotes.content: Igbo culture values humor as a way to cope with hardship. Even at funerals, there are moments of laughter as people share fond memories.

culturalNotes.title: Don't Cross the Line
culturalNotes.content: Jokes about someone's parent, child, or poverty are never acceptable. Teasing should be light and mutual.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Make me laugh' in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Mee ka m chịa ọchị' = cause me to laugh.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ọ bụ egwuregwu' mean?
practiceExercises.explanation: It means 'it's just play' – not serious.

practiceExercises.question: Which of these is a sign of good-natured humor?
How do you respond to a joke that went too far?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'It's not a game' – politely indicate it wasn't funny.

practiceExercises.question: What is the difference between 'ịkpa ọchị' and 'ịkwa emo'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ịkpa ọchị' is light-hearted joking; 'ịkwa emo' is hurtful mockery.

tips: Encourage family jokes at dinner; it builds bonds and language skills.
A self-deprecating joke in Igbo can break the ice and show humility.
Light humor in meetings can ease tension, but keep it professional.
Laugh together daily; it's the shortest path between two hearts.
Different ethnic groups have different humor styles; Igbo humor often involves wordplay.
Watch Igbo comedy skits online
Observe what makes people laugh
When you make a mistake, laugh at yourself

levels.title: Level 45: Celebration
levels.description: Vocabulary for weddings, birthdays, title‑taking: 'I bring lafun,' 'Join the spray,' 'Mama, dance!'

vocabulary.example: Emume ịwa ji na-eme kwa afọ.
Ịwa ji bụ nnukwu emume n'ala Igbo.
Nna m ga-anara ọfịa n'afọ a.
Ha na-atụ ego n'elu nwanyị ahụ na-agba egwu.
A na-ete ndị eze lafụn n'ihu.
E ji nzu kee ha aka.

vocabulary.translation: Mouth / also 'kolanut' in context? No, use 'ọjị'

vocabulary.culturalNote: Sacred nut for welcoming and prayer.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use exhortations: 'Bịa gbaa egwu!', 'Tụọ ego!', 'Ṇụọ mmanya!'.
Use 'a na-eme' (is being done) to describe ongoing celebrations.

dialogue.speaker: Ọkà okwu
dialogue.text: Nnọọ, ndị ọbịa! Bịanu sọpụrụ anyị n'emume ịnye ọfịa nna anyị.
dialogue.translation: Welcome, guests! Come honour us at our father's chieftaincy title ceremony.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ọbịa
dialogue.text: Anyị bịara ịsọpụrụ ya. Ebe ka anyị ga-anọdụ?
dialogue.translation: We came to honour him. Where shall we sit?

dialogue.speaker: Ọkà okwu
dialogue.text: Nọdụnu ala ebe a. Nwata, weta ọjị na mmanya.
dialogue.translation: Sit here. Child, bring kola nut and wine.

dialogue.speaker: Onye ọbịa
dialogue.text: Ka anyị taa ọjị. Ọfịa dị ụtọ!
dialogue.translation: Let us break kola. Chieftaincy is sweet!

dialogue.speaker: Ọkà okwu
dialogue.text: Ugbu a, nne anyị ga-agba egwu. Tụọnụ ego n'elu ya!
dialogue.translation: Now, our mother will dance. Spray money on her!

culturalNotes.title: Chieftaincy Titles
culturalNotes.content: Taking a title (ịnye ọfịa) is a way to honour distinguished members of the community. It involves ceremonies, payment, and often a new name like 'Onowu', 'Ichiedu', etc.

culturalNotes.title: Spraying Money
culturalNotes.content: At celebrations, guests spray money on dancers and celebrants. It is a sign of appreciation and blessing, not just a display of wealth. The money is often picked up by attendants.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'ịwa ji'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ịwa ji' is the New Yam Festival.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Spray money' in Igbo?
What is 'lafụn' used for?
practiceExercises.explanation: Lafun (camwood) is applied to the skin during ceremonies for blessing and beautification.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'ọjị' symbolize?
practiceExercises.explanation: Kola nut is offered to guests as a sign of welcome and used in prayers.

practiceExercises.question: Who typically receives a chieftaincy title?
practiceExercises.explanation: Titles are given to elders and notable individuals.

tips: Take children to cultural festivals and explain the events in Igbo.
If you attend a Nigerian wedding, carry small notes to spray – it's part of the fun.
If you are honoured with a title, learn the responses: 'Daalụ, ndị mụrụ m'.
Traditional weddings involve all these elements – you'll be expected to dance and spray!
Title names vary by clan; know the specific titles of your spouse's community.
Always accept kola nut when offered
Dance when called upon
Bring money to spray – it's a blessing

levels.title: Level 46: Tradition and Custom
levels.description: Explaining cultural norms: 'In the past we did X, but now we do Y.'
learningObjectives: Learn to describe past vs present customs

vocabulary.example: Ọ bụ omenala anyị ịkọ ugbo.
N'oge ochie, a na-eli ozu n'ụlọ.
N'oge ugbu a, a na-eli n'ebe a na-eli ozu.
N'oge ochie, a naghị anabata ịgba alụkwaghịm.
Ọtụtụ ndị na-ahọrọ ịlụ otu nwanyị ugbu a.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'N'oge ochie... ma n'oge ugbu a...' (In the past... but nowadays...).
examples: N'oge ochie, a na-akụ ọkpọ, ma n'oge ugbu a, a naghị.
Ụmụaka na-agba ọsọ n'oge ochie, ma ugbu a ha na-eji igwe.
grammarPoints.pattern: N'oge ochie + [custom] , ma n'oge ugbu a + [new custom]

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'n'ihi na' (because) or 'maka' (for the sake of).
examples: Ha kwụsịrị ya n'ihi na ọ bụ ihe ize ndụ.
Anyị na-eme nke a maka ịsọpụrụ ndị nna anyị.

dialogue.speaker: Nwa nwa
dialogue.text: Nna nna, gịnị ka ndị Igbo na-eme n'oge ochie?
dialogue.translation: Grandfather, what did the Igbo do in the olden days?

dialogue.speaker: Nna nna
dialogue.text: N'oge ochie, anyị na-efe arụsị, ma n'oge ugbu a, ọtụtụ anyị bụ Ndị Kraịst.
dialogue.translation: In the olden days, we worshipped idols, but nowadays most of us are Christians.

dialogue.speaker: Nwa nwa
dialogue.text: Gịnị mere unu ji gbanwee?
dialogue.translation: Why did you change?

dialogue.speaker: Nna nna
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ n'ihi ozioma ndị ozi ala ọzọ wetara. Ọ bụkwa nhọrọ anyị.
dialogue.translation: Because of the gospel the missionaries brought. It was also our choice.

dialogue.speaker: Nwa nwa
dialogue.text: Ma ụfọdụ omenala ka dị, dịka ịwa ji.
dialogue.translation: But some traditions remain, like the New Yam Festival.

dialogue.speaker: Nna nna
dialogue.text: Ee, anyị ga-echekwa ha maka ọdịnihu.
dialogue.translation: Yes, we must preserve them for the future.

culturalNotes.title: Cultural Evolution
culturalNotes.content: Igbo culture has changed significantly due to colonialism, Christianity, and globalization. However, many traditions are revived and adapted, blending old and new.

culturalNotes.title: Respect for Both
culturalNotes.content: Elders may hold onto traditions, while youths embrace modernity. Mutual respect is key. It is acceptable to explain 'In the past we did X, but now we do Y' without judgment.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'In the past' in Igbo?
What does 'gbanwee' mean?
How do you express 'because of'?
Which tradition is still widely practiced?
practiceExercises.explanation: New Yam Festival is celebrated across Igboland.

practiceExercises.question: Why did many Igbo convert to Christianity?
practiceExercises.explanation: Missionaries brought Christianity, and many chose to convert.

tips: Share stories of how things were when you were young; it connects generations.
Ask your elders about 'oge ochie' – they love to share and you'll learn a lot.
When working in communities, understanding cultural changes helps you adapt.
Discuss which traditions you want to keep and which to adapt as a couple.
Some communities are more traditional than others; observe local practices.
Use contrast phrases to discuss change
Respect both old and new ways
Ask 'Gịnị mere?' to understand reasons

levels.title: Level 47: Phone Calls
levels.description: Bad networks: 'Hello, can you hear me?' 'Cut the call and call me back,' 'I am on the line.'

vocabulary.example: Ị nụrụ m? Ụda adịghị mma.

vocabulary.culturalNote: Hang up and I'll call you back.

vocabulary.example: M ga-akpọghachi gị n'ime nkeji ise.
Hapụrụ m gị ozi, ị nwetaghị ya?

grammarPoints.explanation: Use verb roots: 'Bepụ!', 'Kpọghachi!', 'Chere!'.
Use 'nwụrụ anwụ' (dead), 'adịghị mma' (not good), 'na-akụda' (drops).
examples: Anaghị m anụ ihe ị na-ekwu

dialogue.speaker: Chika
dialogue.text: Hello, ọ bụ Ngozi?
dialogue.translation: Hello, is it Ngozi?

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Ee, ọ bụ m. Kedu, Chika?
dialogue.translation: Yes, it's me. How are you, Chika?

dialogue.speaker: Chika
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma. Ma ụda adịghị mma. Ị nụrụ m?
dialogue.translation: I'm fine. But the network is bad. Can you hear me?

dialogue.speaker: Ngozi
dialogue.text: Anụghị m nke ọma. Biko, bepụ, kpọghachikwa m.
dialogue.translation: I can't hear well. Please, hang up and call me back.

dialogue.speaker: Chika
dialogue.text: Ọ dị mma, m ga-akpọghachi gị ozugbo.
dialogue.translation: Okay, I will call you back immediately.

culturalNotes.title: Missed Call Culture
culturalNotes.content: In Nigeria, it's common to 'flash' – call and hang up so the person calls you back, saving your credit. It's a social code: one ring means 'call me', two rings may mean 'I'm on my way'.

culturalNotes.title: Network Woes
culturalNotes.content: Network issues are so frequent that phrases like 'Ụda adịghị mma' are part of daily conversation. Patience is key.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'Can you hear me?' on the phone?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ị nụrụ m?' = Did you hear me?

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Bepụ, m ga-akpọghachi gị' mean?
options: Hang up, I will call you back
Don't hang up, I'll call back

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ekwentị m nwụrụ anwụ' mean?
How do you ask for someone's phone number?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Nọmba gị bụ ole?' is polite and clear.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'ịkụ ọkụ' in phone context?

tips: Teach children to answer politely: 'Hello, onye ka m na-ekwu okwu?'.
If network is bad, don't stress – say 'Ụda adịghị mma' and agree to call back.
For important calls, ask 'Ị nụrụ m nke ọma?' to confirm clarity.
End calls with love: 'Ka anyị nụkwuo ọzọ, ezi m'.
Different networks have different reputations; MTN is often 'na-ebu ụda'.
Speak clearly and slowly
Confirm hearing with 'Ị nụrụ m?'
Don't be afraid to ask for a call back

levels.title: Level 48: Stating Opinions
levels.description: Stating views without starting a fight: 'In my opinion,' 'I beg to differ.'

vocabulary.translation: In my opinion / In my view
vocabulary.example: N'uche m, ọ bụghị ezi mkpebi.
Echere m na anyị kwesịrị ichere.
Ọ dị m ka ọ ga-aka mma ma anyị gbanwee.
M ga-ekweta na ị ziri ezi.
Ekwela m ka ị mata na enwere m nsogbu.
N'akụkụ ọzọ, ụfọdụ ndị nwere ike ịhọrọ ụzọ ọzọ.
Ọ bụ ihe ezi uche ịgbaso iwu.
E nwere ike na m mehiere.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use softening phrases: 'N'uche m', 'Ọ dị m ka', 'Echere m na'.
examples: N'uche m, ọ dị oke ọnụ.
Ọ dị m ka anyị ga-ezukọ tupu oge eruo.

grammarPoints.explanation: Start with 'Anaghị m ekweta' or 'E nwere m nsogbu na nke ahụ' (I have a problem with that). Avoid 'Ị ghaghị' (you must).
examples: E nwere m nsogbu na echiche gị.

dialogue.speaker: Obi
dialogue.text: Echere m na anyị kwesịrị ịzụta ụgbọala ọhụrụ.
dialogue.translation: I think we should buy a new car.

dialogue.speaker: Nkechi
dialogue.text: Anaghị m ekweta. N'uche m, nke ochie ka na-arụ ọrụ nke ọma.
dialogue.translation: I don't agree. In my opinion, the old one still works well.

dialogue.speaker: Obi
dialogue.text: Ọ dị m ka anyị ga-efunahụ ego ma ọ bụrụ na anyị echere.
dialogue.translation: It seems to me we will lose money if we wait.

dialogue.speaker: Nkechi
dialogue.text: E nwere ike, ma e nwekwara ihe ize ndụ ịzụta ugbu a.
dialogue.translation: Maybe, but there are also risks buying now.

dialogue.speaker: Obi
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ ihe ezi uche ka anyị tụlee nhọrọ abụọ ahụ.
dialogue.translation: It is reasonable for us to consider both options.

culturalNotes.title: Avoiding Confrontation
culturalNotes.content: In Igbo culture, open disagreement with elders or superiors is avoided. Instead, phrases like 'E nwere ike' (maybe) or 'Ọ dị m ka' (it seems to me) are used to soften dissent.

culturalNotes.title: Consensus Building
culturalNotes.content: Traditional Igbo meetings aim for consensus, not majority vote. Disagreements are expressed indirectly to preserve harmony.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'In my opinion' politely?
What is a polite way to disagree?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Anaghị m ekweta' simply states disagreement without blame.

practiceExercises.question: Which phrase shows you are open to other views?
How do you say 'It seems to me'?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ọ dị m ka' is a gentle opener.

practiceExercises.question: What does 'Ọ bụ ihe ezi uche' mean?

tips: Encourage children to express opinions with 'Echere m na...' – it builds confidence.
In group discussions, use 'N'uche m' – it sounds thoughtful, not arrogant.
Mastering these phrases is essential for meetings and negotiations.
Disagree with love: 'Anaghị m ekweta, ma a hụrụ m gị n'anya'.
In some communities, you must never openly disagree with an elder; use 'E nwere ike'.
Soften your opinion with 'N'uche m'
Acknowledge the other side
Stay calm and listen

levels.title: Level 49: Telling a Story
levels.description: Narrative structure: setting, problem, climax, resolution. 'Let me tell you what happened...'

vocabulary.culturalNote: Let me tell you a story.

vocabulary.example: Na mmalite, e nwere otu nwoke...
N'ihe dị ka elekere anọ, ọ lọtara.
Mmegharị ndị a mere ngwa ngwa.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'mgbe ahụ' (then), 'na mberede' (suddenly), 'n'ikpeazụ' (finally).
examples: Mgbe ahụ, ọ hụrụ enyi ya.

grammarPoints.explanation: Common openings: 'Ka m kọrọ gị akụkọ...', 'N'oge gara aga...', 'Otu mgbe...'.
examples: Ka m kọrọ gị ihe mere.
N'oge gara aga, e nwere otu eze.

dialogue.speaker: Nne nne
dialogue.text: Ụmụ m, bịanu nụrụ akụkọ. Ka m kọrọ unu ihe mere n'oge gara aga.
dialogue.translation: My children, come and hear a story. Let me tell you what happened in the past.

dialogue.speaker: Ụmụaka
dialogue.text: Ee, nne nne, anyị chọrọ ịnụ!
dialogue.translation: Yes, grandmother, we want to hear!

dialogue.speaker: Nne nne
dialogue.text: Otu mgbe, e nwere oke na ọdụm. Ha bụ enyi...
dialogue.translation: Once upon a time, there was a rat and a lion. They were friends...

dialogue.speaker: Nne nne
dialogue.text: Mgbe ahụ, ọdụm tọrọ atọ n'ọnya. Oke nụrụ akwa ya wee bịa nyere ya aka.
dialogue.translation: Then, the lion got trapped in a net. The rat heard his cry and came to help.

dialogue.speaker: Nne nne
dialogue.text: N'ikpeazụ, oke tara ụdọ ahụ, hapụ ọdụm. Ọdụm wee kelee ya.
dialogue.translation: Finally, the rat chewed the rope and freed the lion. The lion thanked him.

dialogue.speaker: Ụmụaka
dialogue.text: Ọ bụ akụkọ mara mma!
dialogue.translation: It's a beautiful story!

culturalNotes.title: Oral Storytelling
culturalNotes.content: Storytelling (ịkọ akụkọ) is a cherished tradition. Grandmothers often tell folk tales with animals (trickster tortoise, greedy hyena) that teach moral lessons.

culturalNotes.title: Call and Response
culturalNotes.content: Sometimes the storyteller uses call-and-response: 'Ọ kà? ' (And then?) – listeners respond 'Kà!' to keep the story going.

practiceExercises.question: How do you start a story in Igbo?
practiceExercises.explanation: 'Ka m kọrọ gị akụkọ' = Let me tell you a story.

practiceExercises.question: What is 'mgbe ahụ' used for?
What does 'ọgwụgwụ' mean?
Which animal is often the trickster in Igbo folktales?
practiceExercises.explanation: Mbekwu the tortoise is famous for cunning.

practiceExercises.question: How do you say 'One day' in a story?

tips: Tell bedtime stories in Igbo; children learn narrative structure and vocabulary.
Practice telling a story about your day using 'Nke mbụ... mgbe ahụ... n'ikpeazụ'.
Storytelling is a powerful presentation tool. Use 'Ka m kọrọ unu otu akụkọ' to engage an audience.
Share stories from your childhood with your spouse – it builds intimacy.
Different communities have distinct folk heroes; learn the stories of your area.
Use time words to structure events
Start with 'Otu mgbe' or 'Ka m kọrọ'
End with a moral or lesson

levels.title: Level 50: Test 5 – Full Conversation
levels.description: Final Assessment: Full, unstructured conversation – meet a stranger at an event, introduce yourself, discuss where you’re from, current affairs, family, joke, and exchange contact info seamlessly.

Nne m na nna m nọ ebe a.
practiceExercises.explanation: Clear statement about marital status and children.

practiceExercises.question: He tells a joke and you laugh. What do you say?
